* LDA and IRC sections 4911 and 162(e) were enacted at different times and for different purposes
* LDA requires organizations to register and report lobbying activities to provide greater public disclosure of attempts to influence federal officials
* IRC sections 4911 and 162(e) do not facilitate public disclosure of lobbying, but serve other purposes: IRC section 4911 sets limits on lobbying by 501(c)(3) organizations, and IRC section 162(e) denies tax deductibility of certain lobbying expenses for businesses
* LDA registration and reporting requirements include identifying the registering organization, client, lobbyists, general and specific issues, and organizations substantially affiliated with the client
* LDA includes minimum dollar thresholds for registration and reporting, with organizations required to register if they have employees who lobby and their total lobbying expenses exceed $20,500 during a 6-month reporting period
* Organizations using an IRC definition for tax purposes can use it for LDA reporting, but must use the LDA definition for legislative branch lobbying and the applicable IRC definition for executive branch lobbying
* Differences between LDA and IRC lobbying definitions can affect who must register and report, the number of organizations using each definition, and the lobbying expenses reported

</summary>

• Developing category strategies

* In 1993, the Institute of Medicine reported that approximately 60,000 military personnel were used as human experimental subjects during secret U.S. chemical weapons programs during World War II.
* VA lacked information about individuals who were exposed during these tests, leading to a series of letters between Members of Congress, the President, and the Secretary of Defense.
* In response, the Deputy Secretary of Defense issued a memo releasing all individuals from nondisclosure restrictions, tasking military departments to declassify and provide information to VA, and establishing a task force to monitor DOD's efforts.
* The Chemical Weapons Exposure Study Task Force identified approximately 6,400 servicemembers and civilians potentially exposed to mustard, lewisite, and other chemical substances.
* In 2000, the acting Secretary of Veterans Affairs requested assistance from the Secretary of Defense in obtaining information about Project 112 tests.
* DOD identified 5,842 servicemembers and estimated that 350 civilians were potentially exposed during Project 112 tests.
* DOD stopped actively searching for additional individuals potentially exposed during Project 112 tests without conducting a cost-benefit analysis.
* Since then, additional individuals have been identified through non-DOD sources, highlighting the need for a more comprehensive and transparent approach to identifying and notifying potentially exposed individuals.

* DOD's efforts to identify individuals potentially exposed during chemical and biological tests outside of Project 112 have faced challenges, including a lack of clear objectives, inconsistent scope, limited use of existing information, and inadequate oversight.
* DOD's current effort lacks transparency, as it has not worked with veterans or veterans service organizations and has not kept Congress and the public fully informed about the status of its efforts.
* DOD and VA have had limited success in notifying individuals who were potentially exposed to chemical and biological substances during Project 112 tests or testing that occurred outside of Project 112.
* To address these challenges, DOD should conduct a cost-benefit analysis, clarify the scope of its efforts, coordinate with other entities, and increase transparency through regular updates to Congress, veterans service organizations, and the public.
</summary>

* The use of unfinished firearm receivers, or "80 percent receivers," and firearm parts for assembly in Mexico is an emerging trend among criminal organizations.

• Superfund program was established under CERCLA in 1980 to clean up hazardous waste sites
• As of December 1996, there were 1,210 sites on the National Priorities List (NPL)

• Incineration used as cleanup remedy at some Superfund sites
• Three incinerators operating at Superfund sites as of October 1996: Bayou Bonfouca, Times Beach, and Baird and McGuire
• Incineration involves preparing and burning wastes, collecting ash, and filtering gases
• Fixed facility hazardous waste incinerators require RCRA permits and inspections
• Superfund incinerators not required to have permits but must meet RCRA standards
• EPA uses site-specific standards, engineering controls, monitoring, and 24-hour oversight to ensure safe operation
• EPA has not fully implemented all planned methods to promote safe operation, including inspections and information-sharing
• Lessons learned from one Superfund incineration project not consistently applied to others
• Recommendations include having RCRA inspectors evaluate Superfund incinerators and documenting lessons learned.

• MWDs (Military Working Dogs) are defined as canines used by the Department of Defense (DOD) for various duties, including explosive and illegal narcotic detection, patrol, tracking, and other requirements.
• Robby's Law, enacted in 2000, requires the military to make MWDs available for adoption when they are no longer needed, giving priority to former handlers and those capable of humanely caring for the dogs.
• During the MWD disposition process, Army Veterinary Corps Officers provide recommendation letters and consultation/referral forms for each dog's medical condition and suitability for adoption.
• Prevalent medical conditions among adopted MWDs include skin conditions or ear infections, dental disease or injury, arthritis or degenerative joint disease, and degenerative lumbo-sacral stenosis.
• The average age of most adopted MWDs is about 9 years old, and preventative care is recommended regardless of their medical conditions.
• Assistance with veterinary care for adopted MWDs is available through nonprofit organizations like the U.S. War Dogs Association and the American Humane organization.
• Veterinary services for adopted MWDs can be purchased through DOD if the owner has access to medical services at military installations.
• The number of MWDs adopted, transferred, or euthanized has varied over the past 5 years, with the highest numbers in 2012 and 2013 due to decreased need during deployments.
• Available data indicates that some MWDs were never deployed outside of their assigned military installations or did not qualify for the program due to performance or medical reasons.
• The potential costs for treating prevalent medical conditions vary based on factors such as the course of treatment, underlying cause, and geographic location.
• There are no standardized medical treatment protocols for animals, making it difficult to estimate treatment costs for specific conditions.

* The Comanche helicopter program was established in 1983 to replace the Army's light helicopter fleet with a low-cost, lightweight, advanced technology helicopter.
* The program faced challenges due to the need to develop advanced technologies, maintainability goals, and budgetary constraints.
* In response to budgetary constraints, the Secretary of Defense restructured the Comanche helicopter program in 1994, reducing funding and extending the development phase.
* The Army proposed a restructure that allowed for the acquisition of six "early operational capability" aircraft, but operational testing would not begin until after the low-rate initial production decision was made.
* The Comanche program faced risks associated with high concurrency, software development problems, maintainability issues, and weight growth.

* High concurrency:
  * The program proceeded into low-rate initial production before significant initial operational testing was completed.
  * Establishing programs with no concurrency or a low degree of concurrency avoids risks of production items having to be retrofitted and system design not being thoroughly tested.
  * Aircraft systems, such as the T-45A and C-17, that entered low-rate initial production before successfully completing initial operational testing experienced significant modifications.

  * Fixes to individual compiler software problems are not being shared with all developers, leading to delays in qualification testing of the compilation system.

* HUD had 9,386 employees as of February 1999

* Benefits limited to about one-fourth of eligible individuals due to budgetary constraints

** Community Development:

* Funding may also be distributed directly to nonprofit groups and organizations

** Housing Finance:

** Regulatory Issues:

* Supports fair housing programs and enforces federal fair housing laws

* HUD proposed a total budget of about $34 billion in discretionary outlays for fiscal year 2000, a 9-percent increase in budget authority over fiscal year 1999
* Proposed budget includes renewal of all Section 8 rental assistance contracts, increases to virtually all program areas, and continued increases to programs addressing communities' worst case needs
* Proposed budget includes 19 new initiatives and programs, 7 of which are set-asides totaling $210 million
* HUD's fiscal year 2000 budget request includes significant funding increases in several ongoing programs, including Section 8 contract renewals
* HUD's Section 8 housing assistance program requires review due to past inconsistencies in budget proposals and unexpended balances

<summary>

• The Social Security Administration (SSA) is the largest producer and collector of personal information in the US
• SSA is responsible for issuing Social Security Numbers (SSNs) and maintaining wage and earnings records
• SSA's disclosure policy has evolved over time, with the enactment of the Freedom of Information Act and the Privacy Act
• The Privacy Act requires agencies to inform individuals of the collection and use of their personal information, and prohibits disclosure without consent except in certain circumstances
• SSA's disclosure policy is more restrictive than the Privacy Act and allows sharing of nontax information with law enforcement under certain conditions
• Conditions for sharing information with law enforcement include fraud or criminal activity in Social Security programs, nonviolent crimes, and violent and serious crimes

• Regarding fraud or criminal activity in Social Security programs:
    • SSA will provide information necessary to investigate or prosecute fraud or other criminal activity
    • This includes state welfare/social services programs such as Medicare or Medicaid, unemployment compensation, food stamps, and general assistance

• Regarding violent and serious crimes:
    • SSA may disclose information when a violent crime has been committed and the individual has been indicted or convicted
    • The penalty for conviction must be incarceration for at least 1 year and a day
    • SSA might also disclose information when a person violates parole and the violent crime provisions of the original conviction have been met

</summary>

<summary>

• The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) was passed in 1976 and amended in 1984 to establish a national policy for managing hazardous waste
• RCRA governs the management of hazardous waste from generation to final disposal to minimize threats to human health and the environment
• EPA has identified criteria for hazardous waste, including specific types listed by source or characteristics that make waste hazardous
• Waste from both current and past industrial operations is regulated, including waste associated with cleanups
• Proposals have been introduced since 1995 to amend the application of RCRA’s requirements to remediation waste
• EPA identified remediation waste as a key area for statutory reform due to its implementation costs outweighing environmental benefits
• Three requirements under RCRA that pose barriers to managing remediation waste are land disposal restrictions, minimum technological requirements, and requirements for permits
• Land disposal restrictions and minimum technological requirements primarily add costs by setting stringent standards for treating and disposing of hazardous waste
• Requirements for permits add time and costs to some cleanups, potentially discouraging the cleanup of some sites

</summary>

• Land disposal restrictions:
  • Prohibit parties from disposing of hazardous waste on land unless it has been treated to minimize threats
  • Set stringent treatment standards for hazardous waste that has been restricted from land disposal
  • Complying with these requirements can be costly and complex, especially for cleanups involving large volumes of waste

• Minimum technological requirements:
  • Apply to facilities that treat or dispose of hazardous waste, including temporary waste piles
  • Require facilities to meet specific design and operating specifications, such as liners, leachate collection systems, and monitoring systems
  • These requirements can be counterproductive for some cleanups and unnecessarily increase costs

• Requirements for permits:
  • Prohibit the treatment, storage, or disposal of hazardous waste without a permit
  • Obtaining a permit involves a step-by-step approach with substantial requirements for documentation and review
  • Parties may try to avoid triggering the permit requirement, potentially leading to less aggressive and less effective cleanup methods.

* Before 1996, Medicare program integrity activities were underfunded due to budget constraints and reduced the ability of contractors to conduct audits and review medical claims.
* HHS advocated for dedicated and stable funding for program integrity activities outside of the annual appropriations process.
* HIPAA established the Medicare Integrity Program (MIP) in 1997 and provided CMS with dedicated funding for program integrity activities.
* MIP funds are used to support contractors' program integrity efforts, including fiscal intermediaries, carriers, PSCs, and MACs.
* MACs are a new type of contractor that will replace intermediaries and carriers by October 2011.
* CMS allocates MIP funds primarily to support contractors' program integrity efforts for the traditional Medicare program.
* MIP provides funds for specific program integrity activities, such as audits, medical review, secondary payer, benefit integrity, and provider education.
* CMS increased funding for program integrity activities from fiscal years 1997 to 2005, with provider education receiving the largest percentage increase and audit and medical review receiving the largest amount of funds overall.
* CMS plans to further increase expenditures for program integrity in fiscal year 2006, with a total of $832 million available for MIP activities.

</summary>

• Passenger screening involves inspecting individuals and property to deter and prevent carriage of dangerous items
• Checked baggage screening involves inspecting baggage to deter, detect, and prevent carriage of dangerous items

• Recurrent training requires 3 hours per week and includes X-ray image interpretation and screening techniques
• FSDs identified a desire for more training in specific areas, including leadership, communication, and supervision
• TSA has acknowledged challenges in recurrent screener training delivery and is taking steps to address these challenges
• TSA has updated basic screener training curriculum and implemented a new dual-function screener training program

• TSA recognizes the importance of Screener Supervisors and has established training programs to enhance their performance and effectiveness.

* Network operates as a single call center providing round-the-clock service since 1999
* Calls are routed to sites with shortest hold times for tax law, account services, and refund status
* Before 1999, calls were routed based on area codes or percentage of staff scheduled

* Best practices in telephone service include setting service-level goals based on customers' needs

• DOD has reversed $592 million of the adjustments, but additional accounting problems were discovered during the reversal process.
• DOD plans to complete all reaudits to correct the accounting errors by September 30, 2002.
• The causes of the accounting errors include complex contracts, numerous ACRNs, and changes in payment allocation terms.

<summary>
• The Internet, which relies on the domain name system to ensure the uniqueness of email and website addresses, has grown significantly in importance for American businesses and consumers, as well as for vital services such as power distribution, health care, law enforcement, and national defense.
• The domain name system functions through a set of rules that determine which top-level domains (TLDs) are recognized by most computers connected to the Internet. The system is managed by a set of 13 root servers, which coordinate the translation of domain names into Internet addresses.
• The U.S. government supported the implementation of the domain name system for nearly a decade, but began a process in 1997 to transition technical responsibility to the private sector. The Department of Commerce issued a White Paper in 1998 outlining the goals of privatization, including stability, competition, representation, and private, bottom-up coordination.
• ICANN, a private, nonprofit organization, was established in 1998 to manage the domain name system. The organization has made progress in increasing competition, but has faced challenges in addressing other guiding principles, such as increasing stability and security, ensuring representation of the Internet community, and using private, bottom-up coordination.
• In response to these challenges, ICANN's president concluded that the organization needed fundamental reform and established an internal committee to recommend options. The committee made important progress on several tasks related to promoting competition, but progress has been slower on activities designed to address other guiding principles.
• Recent reports have highlighted the importance of the domain name system to the stability and security of the entire Internet, and have identified vulnerabilities in commonly used domain name software. The White Paper designated the stability and security of the Internet as the top priority of the transition, and ICANN and the Department of Commerce have entered into agreements to develop operational requirements and security policies to enhance the stability and security of the root servers.
</summary>

* The Secretary of the Interior is responsible for managing these trust funds as trustee for tribes and individuals.
* The Comprehensive Trust Management Plan and the As-Is Trust Business Model Report outline strategies for improving trust management.

* The Special Trustee has not provided the Congress with a timetable for completing trust reforms or a date for OST's termination, hindering oversight and planning.

• However, the departments faced management weaknesses in their efforts to develop the interface, including the lack of a well-defined architecture, a project management lead entity, and a comprehensive project management plan.
• To address these issues, GAO recommended that the departments develop an architecture for the electronic interface, select a lead entity, establish a project management structure, and create and implement a comprehensive project management plan.
• VA and DOD have also implemented two demonstration projects: Bidirectional Health Information Exchange and Laboratory Data Sharing Interface, which focus on exchanging information between existing systems. These projects were mandated by the Bob Stump National Defense Authorization Act of 2003.
• BHIE is an interim step in the departments' overall strategy to create a two-way exchange of electronic medical records and focuses on the two-way, near-real-time exchange of information on shared patients.
• LDSI enables the two departments to share laboratory resources and reduces the need for rekeying orders and transporting specimens.
• The departments have taken important actions on the CHDR initiative, including completing Phase I, developing an architecture, and establishing project accountability and a joint project management structure.

• The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) aims to determine correct taxable income and liability through income tax audits
• Audit quality is crucial for both the audited taxpayer and all other taxpayers
• Nine audit standards define audit quality, covering issues like scope, techniques, reports, and time management
• Workpapers are essential for planning, documenting procedures, supporting technical conclusions, and providing basis for review
• Audit workpapers should be clear, concise, legible, organized, initialed, labeled, dated, indexed, and protect taxpayers' privacy
• Tax adjustments recorded in workpapers must agree with IRS forms and the audit report
• Adequate documentation of audit activity records is necessary
• IRS uses the Examination Quality Measurement System (EQMS) to assess audit quality and identify improvements
• Supervisory review during audits is a primary tool for ensuring adherence to audit standards, but documentation of this review is often lacking

• IRS requires group managers to review audit work to assess quality and ensure standards are met, but documentation of this review is not always present in workpapers
• IRS is drafting changes to the IRM requiring documentation of managerial involvement, including signatures, notations, or summaries of discussions in workpapers

<summary>

* Large financial companies may file for bankruptcy under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code
* Bankruptcy process includes filing of petition, automatic stay, equitable treatment of creditors, and various stages such as first-day motions, disclosure, plan of reorganization, and reorganization
* Secured and unsecured creditors, regulators, and government entities may be involved in the bankruptcy process
* Safe harbor provisions allow certain financial and derivative contracts to be exercised despite the automatic stay
* OLA gives FDIC the authority to resolve large financial companies outside of bankruptcy process
* Chapter 15 of the Bankruptcy Code promotes cooperation between U.S. and foreign parties in cross-border insolvency cases
* Recent legislative proposals attempted to address challenges associated with the reorganization of large financial firms under Chapter 11
* International efforts have focused on strengthening regulatory structures to enable orderly resolution and facilitate cross-border resolutions

**Bankruptcy Process**

* Filing of petition: automatic stay, equitable treatment of creditors
* First-day motions: continued operation of business, financing
* Disclosure: information on assets, liabilities, business affairs
* Plan of reorganization: description of reorganization plan, treatment of creditors
* Reorganization: distribution of proceeds, liquidation, or reorganization of company

**Involved Parties**

* Secured and unsecured creditors: receive different treatment based on their claims
* Regulators: play a role in financial company bankruptcies, often as creditor
* Government entities: may provide DIP financing or prohibit establishment of emergency lending programs
</summary>

<summary>

* The electricity industry consists of four functions: generation, transmission, distribution, and system operations.
* Once electricity is generated, it is transmitted through high-voltage lines to local distributors, then transformed and distributed to consumers.
* System operators manage the flow of electricity using control systems, which have become increasingly important as the industry has modernized.
* The electricity industry has faced challenges in updating its infrastructure to accommodate new technologies and IT systems, leading to a vision for a "smart grid."
* The smart grid aims to improve reliability, facilitate alternative energy sources, and give consumers real-time energy information.
* Federal and state governments have roles in overseeing the electricity industry, with FERC regulating wholesale sales and transmission, and state commissions overseeing distribution and retail sales.

* FERC and NERC have developed cybersecurity standards for protecting electric utility-critical and cyber-critical assets.
* NIST has identified cybersecurity standards for smart grid systems and developed guidelines for secure implementation.

<summary>
• Skills gaps within the federal workforce pose a high risk to the nation, impeding effective public service and mission achievement
• Reasons for skills gaps include insufficient numbers of employees or lack of appropriate skills, exacerbated by budget pressures, changing nature of federal work, and impending retirements
• Challenges in addressing talent needs include outdated personnel systems and functions, such as the classification system, recruiting and hiring, pay system, performance management, and employee engagement
• To remain competitive in the labor market, federal agencies need to examine the value of employees' total compensation and build transparency and fairness into pay decisions
• Key improvements for federal agencies include focusing on values and objectives, analyzing hiring authorities, modernizing the classification system, and promoting effective performance management
</summary>

• Skills gaps in federal workforce pose significant risks:
  • Impedes effective public service and mission achievement
  • Reasons: insufficient numbers, lack of appropriate skills, budget pressures, changing nature of work, impending retirements

• Challenges in addressing talent needs:
  • Outdated personnel systems and functions
  • Classification system: not keeping pace with government's evolving requirements
  • Recruiting and hiring: need applicant-friendly, flexible, and policy-compliant processes
  • Pay system: rewards length of service, not individual performance and contributions
  • Performance management: modern, credible, and effective systems needed, along with dealing with poor performers
  • Employee engagement: sharing promising practices could improve performance

• To remain competitive in labor market:
  • Examine value of employees' total compensation
  • Build transparency and fairness into pay decisions

• Key improvements for federal agencies:
  • Focus on values and objectives
  • Analyze hiring authorities
  • Modernize classification system
  • Promote effective performance management

<summary>

* The USDA and FSIS are responsible for ensuring the safety of meat, poultry, and certain egg products under the Federal Meat Inspection Act, Poultry Products Inspection Act, and Egg Products Inspection Act.
* The FDA is responsible for ensuring the safety of all other foods, including fruits and vegetables, dairy products, seafood, and certain canned, frozen, and packaged foods under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act and the Public Health Service Act.
* Both agencies work to ensure food safety through a regulatory system of preventive controls called Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Point (HACCP) system.
* FDA and FSIS inspect food facilities to verify HACCP plan implementation and enforce regulatory requirements.
* Following September 11, 2001, the federal government intensified efforts to address potential deliberate contamination of agriculture and food products.
* The Public Health Security and Bioterrorism Preparedness and Response Act of 2002 was enacted to enhance food, drug, and water industries' safety and security.
* FDA and USDA have taken actions to better protect the food supply against deliberate contamination, such as hiring new investigators, participating in exercises, and working with stakeholders.
* FDA and USDA issued voluntary security guidelines to the food-processing industry in 2002 to help identify ways to enhance security.
* Industry officials believe that most large food-processing facilities already have security plans and that the guidelines are reasonable, but they do not want government regulation.

</summary>

* The largest interagency contracting vehicles include the MAS program, MACs, GWACs, and enterprisewide contracts
* GSA manages the MAS program, which is the largest governmentwide buying program for commercial goods and services
* Agencies pay fees for using other agencies' contracts, which cover administrative costs
* Enterprisewide contracts allow agencies to reduce administrative overhead and avoid interagency contract fees
* In fiscal year 2008, federal agencies spent $60 billion through these contracts
* MACs and enterprisewide contracts have limited governmentwide policy for oversight and management
* The total number of MACs and enterprisewide contracts is unknown due to insufficient data in the official procurement database
* Concerns include contract duplication, increased costs, and missed opportunities to leverage the government's buying power
* The Army and DHS are examples of agencies that established their own MACs and enterprisewide contracts for IT hardware and services
* GSA faces challenges in effectively managing the MAS program due to lack of transactional data, limited use of pricing tools, and a decentralized management structure

<summary>

* The baby boom generation, born between 1946 and 1964, is approaching retirement age, leading to a significant increase in the aged dependency ratio.
* By 2030, the aged dependency ratio will reach 35%, meaning fewer than three workers for every person age 65 or older.
* Social Security policies have been changed to encourage older workers to continue working, such as eliminating the reduction of benefits for those with earnings after the normal retirement age and increasing the delayed retirement credit.
* The Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 (ADEA) promotes the employment of older persons based on ability and prohibits age discrimination in employment.
* The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) enforces ADEA and other federal statutes prohibiting employment discrimination.
* Pension laws encourage employers to establish and maintain pension plans, which can influence the work decisions of older individuals.
* Older workers are increasingly participating in the labor force, especially among females age 55-64, and are expected to continue doing so.
* Labor force participation rates of older males have been stable but are projected to increase in the future.
* Older workers are a growing proportion of all workers, particularly in white-collar occupations, and are expected to make relatively greater gains in earnings than their younger counterparts.
* Employers are using various arrangements, such as rehiring retirees, reduced work schedules, and job sharing, to retain older workers.

</summary>

<summary>

* The Visa Waiver Program (VWP) was established in 1986 as a pilot program and permanently established in 2000 to facilitate legitimate travel for business or tourism, boosting international business and tourism, and creating substantial economic benefits for the United States.
* In 2002, the Homeland Security Act of 2002 established the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and gave it responsibility for establishing visa policy, including the VWP. DHS created the Visa Waiver Program Office in 2007 to oversee VWP activities and monitor participating countries' adherence to program requirements.
* Since 9/11, Congress passed several laws to strengthen border security policies, including the Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act of 2002, which increased the frequency of assessments of each country's continued participation in the VWP and added security requirements for all VWP countries.
* In 2008, DHS implemented the Electronic System for Travel Authorization (ESTA) to collect passenger data and complete security checks on the data before passengers board a U.S. bound carrier. ESTA notifies passengers of program ineligibility before they embark for the United States, reducing the burden on passengers and simplifying travel for many.
* DHS has made progress in negotiating information-sharing agreements with VWP countries, but only half of the countries have entered into all required agreements, and many of those agreements have not been implemented. The 9/11 Act requires VWP countries to enter into agreements to share information regarding lost or stolen passports and report such information to the United States.

</summary>

* DHS, State, and Justice have made some progress in entering into the required agreements, but many have not been implemented due to concerns regarding privacy and data protection, as well as the sensitive nature of the terms of the agreements.
* The value and quality of information received through these agreements vary, with some partner countries more willing to share data on known or suspected terrorists than others, and some lacking the technical capacity to provide all information typically obtained through HSPD-6 agreements.

<summary>

• State child welfare systems consist of complex policies and programs to protect children, with growing caseloads straining their ability to keep up
• From 1984 to 1995, foster care population grew from 276,000 to 494,000, with 261,000 children supported by federal funds
• Federal government plays a role in financing foster care and establishing minimum procedural requirements
• States must make reasonable efforts to prevent child removals, provide services, and find permanent placements
• Permanency planning process includes developing a case plan, reviewing it every 6 months, and holding a permanency hearing within 18 months
• Some states have enacted laws to shorten the time between entering foster care and the first permanency hearing
• Initiatives to expedite the permanency process include low-cost programs, expediting termination of parental rights, and concurrent planning

• Arizona's Housing Assistance Program reunited 939 children with their families, saving over $1 million in foster care costs
• Colorado's concurrent planning approach achieved permanent placement for 87% of children within a year of initial placement
• Ohio's requirement for earlier permanency hearings aimed to expedite the process but may have increased long-term foster care placements
• Kentucky's project to shorten termination of parental rights faced challenges in changing caseworkers' and legal system's views on termination
• Evaluation data is lacking for many initiatives, making it difficult to assess their overall impact

</summary>

<summary>

- The DATA Act expanded federal transparency legislation by requiring disclosure of federal agency expenditures and linking spending information to federal program activities.
- OMB and Treasury are responsible for leading government-wide implementation, with key components being accuracy, completeness, and consistency of federal spending data.
- Steps taken to help agencies meet reporting requirements include issuing policy guidance, establishing data definition standards, and conducting meetings with agencies to assess readiness.

* Policy guidance:
  * OMB issued initial guidance in May 2015 and subsequent guidance in May and November 2016.
  * Agencies directed to implement data definition standards, use standard data exchange formats, and link financial and award systems.

* Data definition standards:
  * 57 standardized data element definitions established for reporting federal spending information.
  * Agencies to report financial and award level data, link systems using unique award identifiers, and assure data validity and reliability.
</summary>

• OSC, an agency without in-house contracting staff, uses ARC, a self-supporting government enterprise, for contracting support.
• The agreement between OSC and ARC involves interagency contracting, which requires effective management due to its challenges and recent designation as a high-risk area.
• ARC's sole-source justification for contracting with MPRI for an organizational assessment lacked sufficient information and did not follow proper competition procedures.
• Competition requirements were not met, as no documentation showed that MPRI's proposal was compared to others or that efforts were made to ensure offers from multiple sources.
• The justification did not demonstrate that MPRI's unique qualifications or the nature of the acquisition required an exception to full and open competition.
• ARC contracting officials relied on OSC's input and did not question the justification, while OSC officials assumed it was adequate.
• OSC hired an intermittent consultant, Alan J. Hicks, using the appointment authority under 5 U.S.C. § 3109, and his tasks were consistent with OPM regulations.
• OSC employees have limited options for addressing prohibited personnel practice allegations against the Special Counsel or Deputy Special Counsel, as all ultimately report to them.
• To address potential conflicts of interest, OSC could be afforded alternative means, such as an external investigation through an independent entity or expanded MSPB appeal rights.
• ARC and OSC agreed with GAO's recommendations to improve contracting procedures and oversight.

• VA's mission is to promote health, welfare, and dignity of veterans through medical care, benefits, social support, and memorials
• Three major components: Veterans Benefits Administration (VBA), Veterans Health Administration (VHA), and National Cemetery Administration (NCA)
• Approximately 340,000 employees in 167 medical centers, 800 community-based outpatient clinics, 300 veterans centers, 56 regional offices, and 131 national and 90 state or tribal cemeteries
• IT infrastructure provides backbone for medical centers, veteran-facing systems, benefits delivery systems, memorial services, and all other IT systems

• VA operates approximately 240 information systems, manages 314,000 desktop computers and 30,000 laptops, and administers nearly 460,000 network user accounts
• IT systems used for determination of benefits, benefits claims processing, patient admission to hospitals and clinics, and access to health records
• VBA relies on VBMS for collecting and storing military service records, medical examinations, and treatment records
• VHA's systems provide capabilities to establish and maintain electronic health records

• Two legacy systems, Personnel and Accounting Integrated Data (PAID) and Benefits Delivery Network (BDN), are over 50 years old and in need of modernization or replacement
• VA plans to retire PAID and BDN in 2017 and 2018, respectively
• VA's strategic plan emphasizes increasing veterans' access to benefits and services, eliminating disability claims backlog, and ending veteran homelessness
• VA spent about $3.9 billion in fiscal year 2015 to improve and maintain IT resources

• VA's CIO initiated an effort to transform the Office of Information and Technology (OI&T) in response to the Secretary's goal of achieving a more veteran-focused organization
• Transformation strategy calls for focusing on stabilizing and streamlining processes, mitigating weaknesses, and improving outcomes
• VA designated VA health care as a high-risk area due to IT challenges, including failed modernization of outpatient appointment scheduling system and lack of interoperability with DOD
</summary>

<summary>

* The Medicare program, administered by HCFA, serves about 33 million beneficiaries and processes over 900 million claims annually.
* HCFA is responsible for managing both fee-for-service Medicare and over 400 managed care plans.
* Medicare benefits are divided into Part A (hospital insurance) and Part B (supplementary medical insurance).
* HCFA has around 4,000 employees and oversees over 60 claims processing contractors.
* Two recent acts, HIPAA and BBA, grant HCFA new authority and responsibility to combat fraud and abuse and reform Medicare.

    * HIPAA enhances Medicare's anti-fraud-and-abuse activities and adds new civil and criminal penalties.
    * BBA introduces new health plan options, payment reforms, and consumer protection provisions.

* HCFA faces challenges in implementing legislative reforms, modernizing information systems, and managing the loss of experienced staff.

    * HCFA is reorganizing to better focus on its mission and establish three components focused on beneficiaries, health plans and providers, and Medicaid and other activities.
    * Managers are concerned about the distribution of agency resources, need for specialized expertise, loss of institutional experience, and reorganization issues.
    * HCFA has not adequately ensured that contractors pay only medically necessary or appropriate claims and lacks a method for estimating improper Medicare payments.
    * Managers are beginning to identify the need for staff with specialized technical expertise, such as computer system analysts, survey statisticians, data analysts, market researchers, information management specialists, managed care experts, and health educators.
    * HCFA is planning to hire new people but acknowledges that new employees will need extensive on-the-job training to replace lost expertise.

</summary>

* GSA's Federal Technology Service, in collaboration with the IMC, is responsible for providing federal agencies with access to telecommunications services and solutions to meet mission requirements.
* The FTS2001 program aims to ensure the best service and price for the government and maximize competition for services. Two contracts were awarded to Sprint and MCI WorldCom with minimum revenue guarantees.
** Goals: Ensure continuity of services and prices, maximize competition, respond to changing marketplace, and provide opportunities for small businesses.
** Acquisition Strategy: Networx Universal for comprehensive services and Networx Select for leading edge services with less extensive coverage.

** Inventory: Clear understanding of requirements essential for informed acquisition planning decisions; current status unclear.

* Importance of strong program management for successful transition, including accurate inventories and defined responsibilities.

** Industry Feedback: Strong program management necessary for a smooth transition.

• The Federal Student Aid (FSA) office manages and administers student financial assistance programs under Title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965, providing over $50 billion in aid to 8 million students and families.
• FSA is a President's Management Agenda Performance Budget Office (PBO), established in 1998, with the objectives of improving service, reducing costs, increasing accountability, providing flexibility, integrating information systems, implementing an open delivery system, and ensuring program integrity.
• FSA uses performance agreements for its COO and other senior managers, annual performance plans, and reports to Congress on its performance. It also has a student loan ombudsman and allows for performance bonuses.
• Similar to FSA, other PBOs such as the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office and the Federal Aviation Administration's Air Traffic Organization have also been established with similar objectives and structures.
• The British Next Steps initiative was used as a model for the PBO concept in the United States.
• FSA has taken steps towards developing a strategic direction, including increasing customer and employee satisfaction, reducing unit costs, and implementing a balanced scorecard. However, it has not fully met its reporting requirements to Congress and has faced challenges in integrating systems and ensuring program integrity.
• To improve, FSA needs to clearly report its progress towards integrating systems and enhancing program integrity, disclose the bases of its unit cost calculation, and develop a comprehensive human capital strategy.

* Standard review processes and criteria were used to award scientific research grants, with variations in award size, geographic distribution, duration, and research methods.
* OMB guidelines require recipients to report jobs supported by the Recovery Act on a quarterly basis, and NIH collects this information along with other impacts from grantees and principal investigators.

<summary>

* Transit-oriented development (TOD) is a compact, mixed-use, and walkable neighborhood located near transit, typically within half a mile of a transit station.
* Stakeholders include local transit agencies, state and local departments of transportation, metropolitan-planning organizations, local governments, regional councils, private developers, lenders, and business improvement districts.
* Local transit agencies are responsible for building, maintaining, and operating transit systems, while state and local departments of transportation and metropolitan-planning organizations develop transportation plans and improvement programs.
* Local governments and regional councils have control over land use planning and are responsible for reviewing and granting entitlements for new development projects.
* Private developers decide on and create developments and build and manage housing units and commercial developments.
* Lenders finance developers to design and construct TOD projects.
* Business improvement districts have input on community infrastructure upgrades.
* FTA provides funds for transit projects that may spur TOD but does not have a discrete program for TOD. However, it has expanded its role in recent years through research, partnerships, and a transit-oriented development planning pilot program.

* Factors that support TOD include:
	+ Market demand for real estate: Cities with strong local economies and demand for real estate are more likely to support TOD.
	+ Large parcels of land available for development: Surface parking lots and underutilized industrial land can be converted into TOD.
	+ Resident support for transit and TOD: Cities with high concentrations of young residents and a desire for neighborhoods close to amenities and transit are more supportive of TOD.
	+ Efficient access to jobs and centers of activity: Transit that efficiently connects people to established job and activity centers provides potential for TOD.
* Challenges that hinder TOD include:
	+ Higher construction costs: Transit-oriented developments can be more costly due to the cost of mixed-use buildings and parking garages.
	+ Lenders' reluctance to finance TOD: Some lenders view TOD as riskier due to market risk associated with mixed-use buildings.
	+ Lengthy or discretionary local-development approval processes: Developers face higher risk and more uncertainty when transit-oriented developments are not in line with zoning codes.

<summary>

* The Social Security Administration (SSA) introduced the Personal Earnings and Benefit Estimate Statement (PEBES) in 1988 to provide workers with information about their earnings records and benefit estimates.
* Fewer than 2 percent of workers request these statements each year, but SSA plans to send them automatically to over 70 million workers by fiscal year 2000.
* The goal of the PEBES is to inform the public about benefits available under SSA's programs, assist workers in planning for their financial future, and ensure accurate earnings records.
* The cost of producing and mailing the statements is estimated to be $80 million in fiscal year 2000, with $56 million for production costs and $24 million for personnel costs.
* SSA estimates that 608 staff-years will be required to handle the PEBES workload in fiscal year 2000.
* The benefit estimates provided in the PEBES are based on assumptions about future employment and earnings.
* SSA's approach for estimating future retirement benefits is considered reasonable by experts, but may over- or understate benefits for certain individuals due to special circumstances.
* The PEBES has undergone several revisions based on public feedback, including the addition of estimates for retirement at age 62 and simplification of the design and organization.
* The public's reaction to receiving an unsolicited PEBES has been consistently favorable, with the majority indicating that the information was helpful to their families.
* The current PEBES still provides too much information and is too complex, making it difficult for readers to identify the most important points and navigate the document effectively.
</summary>

<summary>

• SSA administers two programs, DI and SSI, for individuals with disabilities
• DI, established in 1956, is an insurance program providing benefits based on work history and earnings
• SSI, established in 1972, provides a minimum income for individuals with limited income and assets, regardless of work history
• Both programs use the same definition of disability: a medically determinable impairment preventing substantial gainful activity for one year or resulting in death
• Work incentive provisions exist in both programs to encourage beneficiaries to return to work
• Differences in work incentive provisions: DI earnings do not affect cash benefits during trial work period, but benefits may eventually stop if earnings exceed a certain level; SSI earnings can affect cash benefits immediately, but reduction is gradual
• Concurrent beneficiaries, about 14% of SSA's disability population, were likely to have mental impairments, be female, and have a median age of 45

• Approximately 11% of concurrent beneficiaries worked and had a median earned income of about $250 a month
• Most concurrent beneficiaries who worked had mental impairments, with mental illness and mental retardation being the most common
• Median earnings for beneficiaries with mental retardation were nearly half those of beneficiaries with mental illness
• Fewer than 8% of SSI beneficiaries worked, but they had median earnings of $400, compared with about $250 for concurrent beneficiaries
• More than one-quarter of SSI beneficiaries earned $1,000 per month or more, greater than three times the percentage of concurrent beneficiaries with earnings at that level

</summary>

<summary>

* Hurricane Katrina caused significant damage and human casualties in the Gulf Coast region in 2005, leading to $88 billion in relief and recovery funds being appropriated through four emergency supplemental appropriations acts
* FEMA, a DHS component, received $42.6 billion for the Disaster Relief Fund and used it to assist relief and recovery efforts, while other agencies received the remaining $45.4 billion
* FEMA uses mission assignments to task other federal agencies with specific disaster relief work, providing them reimbursable budgetary authority but not actual funds
* Mission assignments include a description of work, estimated dollar amount, completion date, and authorizing signatures
* Performing agencies bill FEMA for reimbursement using the Intra-Governmental Payment and Collection (IPAC) system, which allows for immediate funds transfer upon request
* However, FEMA does not recognize these reimbursements as expenditures until it has reviewed and approved the billing documentation, leading to underreporting of expenditures
* The government lacks a central collection point or framework to consolidate and report on the use of hurricane relief and recovery funds on a governmentwide basis
* Without timely and reliable reporting, decision makers may not have complete information on the status of funding and its use, potentially leading to inefficient allocation or duplication of efforts
* To address this issue, it is recommended that the Director of FEMA take actions to improve reporting in weekly reports to the Appropriations Committees and that the Director of OMB establish a framework for governmentwide reporting on hurricane-related funding

</summary>

	+ Lack transparency and timeliness from a governmentwide perspective

	+ OMB: Establish a framework for governmentwide reporting on hurricane-related funding

• FAA currently allows limited access to national airspace for UAS operations through COAs, experimental certificates, and section 333 exemptions
• FAA is planning for further integration through the UAS Comprehensive Plan and Roadmap, which outline a phased approach to accommodation, integration, and evolution

• Accommodation phase: FAA applies special mitigations and procedures to safely facilitate limited UAS access to the national airspace system
• Integration phase: FAA establishes performance requirements for UAS to increase access to the NAS and begins implementation in the near- to mid-term
• Evolution phase: FAA works to routinely update policies, regulations, procedures, and technologies to support UAS operations in the NAS operational environment

• FAA issued a Notice for Proposed Rulemaking for small UAS operations in February 2015, which could allow greater access to the national airspace with restrictions
• FAA has selected six UAS test sites, which have become operational and have received authorization from FAA for UAS flights, providing operations and safety data for integration efforts
• Some foreign countries allow commercial UAS operations under different legal and regulatory structures, which may offer easier access to testing and airspace for U.S. companies.

* DOD is required to provide Congress with quarterly reports on CERP funds, but some historical data on past projects was lost during database transfers

	+ Brigades responsible for overall execution and fiscal controls
* DOD reporting requirements
	+ Quarterly reports to Congress
	+ Historical data loss during database transfers
* Challenges with personnel and training
	+ Insufficient personnel and training for management and oversight
	+ Lack of personnel affects key duties such as site visits and project oversight.

<summary>

* Six federal agencies undertook 65 initiatives that supported solar energy technology in fiscal years 2010 and 2011.
* Over half of these initiatives (54%) supported solar projects exclusively, while the remaining initiatives supported projects that included other renewable energy technologies.
* Initiatives supported a range of technology advancement activities, from basic research to commercialization, with an emphasis on applied research and demonstration.
* Funding recipients included universities, industry, nonprofit organizations, and federal labs and researchers, primarily through grants and contracts.
* Agencies obligated around $2.6 billion for the solar projects in these initiatives in fiscal years 2010 and 2011.
* DOE was the largest obligator of funds, with over 90% of the total, primarily through the Title XVII Section 1705 Loan Guarantee Program.
* Many initiatives overlapped in key characteristics, such as technology advancement activities, types of technologies, and funding recipients, but did not necessarily lead to duplication of efforts.
* Officials reported engaging in coordination activities to avoid duplication, including joint strategies, monitoring and reporting mechanisms, and resource leveraging.
* Initiatives determined whether applicants had received other sources of federal funding and had policies in place to prevent or permit such funding.

</summary>

* Three types of solar energy technologies were supported: photovoltaics, concentrated solar power, and solar hot water.
* Solar cells convert sunlight directly into electricity, while concentrated solar power uses mirrors or lenses to produce intense heat for electricity generation.
* Solar hot water technologies use collectors to absorb and transfer heat from the sun to water for storage and use.
* Initiatives supported technology advancement activities from basic research to commercialization, with an emphasis on applied research and demonstration.
* Universities, industry, nonprofit organizations, and federal labs and researchers were funding recipients, primarily through grants and contracts.
* Over 30% of the total projects were solar projects, while 70% were not.
* Initiatives supported different types of solar energy technologies and used multiple funding mechanisms, including grants, contracts, cooperative agreements, loans, and other mechanisms.
* Coordination activities included joint strategies, monitoring and reporting mechanisms, and resource leveraging to avoid duplication.

* DOD's risk assessment for military operations using chemical and biological protective equipment is unreliable due to inaccurate inventory data and flawed methodology
* Inventory management issues include miscalculation of requirements, lack of expiration date tracking, and overcounting of equipment before delivery

* Inaccurate inventory data: DOD cannot easily link inventory records, lacks data on suit expiration dates, and has miscalculated requirements and the number of suits available
* Flawed methodology: DOD assesses risk based on individual equipment items rather than ensembles and combines service inventories, obscuring service-specific shortages

* Miscalculation of requirements: Air Force double-counted suit requirements, Army underreported desert pattern suit inventory, and DOD reported suits not yet delivered as on hand
* Lack of expiration date tracking: Army does not record suit expiration information, Navy does not require inventory managers to include expiration dates, and DOD was unable to locate most procurement records for older suits
* Overcounting of equipment: DOD procedures allow reporting suits expected to be delivered as on hand, leading to overestimation of inventory and inaccurate risk assessments.

<summary>

* Program evaluations are systematic studies that address specific questions about program performance using research methods.
* Evaluation is related to performance measurement and reporting, but focuses on assessing a program's effectiveness by isolating its causal impact from external conditions.
* Federal managers reported lacking recent evaluations of their programs in a 2013 survey, but those who had evaluations found them valuable for understanding program performance, assessing effectiveness, and making improvements.
* Barriers to implementing evaluation findings include lack of resources and the need for leadership support and a strong body of evidence.
* Key elements of national or organizational capacity to conduct and use evaluation in decision making include an enabling environment, organizational resources, and the availability of evaluation results.
* The 2014 survey of Performance Improvement Officers (PIOs) found uneven levels of evaluation expertise, organizational support, and use across the government.
* GPRAMA established expectations for evidence-based decision making, changed roles and processes, and required agencies to establish priority goals and report progress publicly.
* OMB has encouraged agencies to build evaluation capacity and use evidence in budget submissions, strategic plans, and performance plans since 2009.
* The Trump Administration's 2018 Budget proposal continues the commitment to building a portfolio of evidence, investing in evaluation infrastructure, and acting on a strong body of evidence to obtain results.

</summary>

<summary>
• The Rehabilitation Act requires federal agencies to promote the employment of individuals with disabilities and provides special hiring authorities for their recruitment.
• Executive Order 13548 set goals for increasing the number of federal employees with disabilities and required agencies to develop plans for achieving these goals. However, many agency plans did not meet OPM's review criteria, and some deficiencies remained unaddressed.
</summary>

• Special hiring authorities:
  • Schedule A excepted service hiring authority allows noncompetitive appointment of individuals with intellectual, severe physical, or psychiatric disabilities.
  • Veterans with 30% or more disability can be noncompetitively appointed and converted to a career appointment.
• Employment goals and plans:
  • Agencies submitted plans for increasing the number of federal employees with disabilities, but many did not meet OPM's review criteria.
  • OPM identified deficiencies, such as lack of numerical goals and absence of a senior-level official responsible for implementation.
  • Agencies were encouraged to address these deficiencies, but some had not done so as of April 2012.
  • OPM provided feedback and examples of effective plans to help agencies improve.

<summary>
• BLM's ALMRS/Modernization project is a large-scale effort to automate land and mineral records and case processing activities, and provide information for land and resource management.
• The project consists of three major components: ALMRS IOC, GCDB, and technology modernization and rehost of selected systems.
• Milestones for development and testing are tight with little tolerance for slippages, and deployment of ALMRS IOC and database conversions also have short installation periods. BLM is taking actions to closely monitor the project status and schedule to avoid slippages.
</summary>

• ALMRS IOC component: provides support for case processing activities and information for land and resource management, including timber sales and grazing leases
• GCDB component: contains geographic coordinates and survey information for land parcels and will be integrated with other databases
• Technology modernization and rehost component: installs computer and telecommunications equipment and converts selected management and administrative systems to a relational database system
• Development milestones: several critical milestones are very close together with little recovery time available to deal with unanticipated problems
• Deployment milestones: final installation of ALMRS IOC and database conversions scheduled for only 15 to 20 working days per state
• BLM is taking actions to closely monitor the project status and schedule to avoid slippages, including periodic oversight reviews, a consolidated project schedule, and advancing the software integration test for build 2.

• IAEA's safeguards objectives are to account for nuclear material and prevent its diversion to nuclear weapons or other proscribed purposes
• IAEA uses various methods to meet these objectives, including inspections, material-accounting measures, containment measures, and surveillance devices
• IAEA has strengthened its safeguards by more aggressively seeking assurances that a country is not pursuing a clandestine nuclear program
• IAEA's Additional Protocol gives the agency greater authority to evaluate all aspects of a country's nuclear activities and resolve inconsistencies
• IAEA faces limitations in its ability to draw conclusions about a country's nuclear activities with absolute assurance
• IAEA has limited information about the nuclear activities of key countries that are not members of the NPT, such as India, Israel, North Korea, and Pakistan
• More than half of NPT signatories have not yet brought the Additional Protocol into force, limiting IAEA's inspection efforts and ability to detect clandestine nuclear programs
• IAEA is facing a human capital crisis as many senior safeguards inspectors and high-level management officials are retiring, potentially compromising the quality of analysis of countries' nuclear programs.

* Agencies must prioritize their efforts, develop contingency plans, and ensure that data exchanges are Year 2000 compliant to minimize the risk of disruptions.
* The federal government's progress in fixing its systems has been slow, with only about 40% of mission-critical systems reported as compliant as of May 1998.

<summary>

* IQA consists of two major elements:
  * First element: OMB developed guidelines by end of fiscal year 2001 for ensuring and maximizing quality, objectivity, utility, and integrity of information.
  * Second element: Federal agencies covered by the Paperwork Reduction Act developed their own guidelines and correction mechanisms by end of fiscal year 2002.
* IQA builds on previous federal efforts to improve information quality, such as OMB Circular A-130 and the Paperwork Reduction Act of 1980.
* OIRA developed governmentwide IQA guidelines and helped agencies meet requirements.
* Challenges in implementing IQA:
  * Lack of IQA information on some independent agencies' websites.
  * Difficulty accessing IQA information on some agencies' websites.
  * Limited resources and potential benefits considered in implementing IQA at some agencies.

<summary>

* Financial intermediaries, including mutual fund companies and banks, raise funds from savers and invest them in the economy
* Banks use deposits for loans or debt securities, while mutual funds invest in securities, primarily bonds and stocks
* The relative importance of bank loans as a source of finance has been declining since the 1960s
* Corporations and households have become less dependent on bank loans for financing, with securitization playing a larger role
* Securitization involves the process of securities issuance replacing bank credit as a source of finance
* The Federal Reserve, ICI, and Flow of Funds Accounts were used to assess the impact of mutual funds on deposits
* The impact of mutual funds on deposits is significant, with mutual fund assets growing rapidly since the late 1980s
* The movement of money from deposits to mutual funds has had little effect on the total supply of loanable and investable funds

* Mutual funds have attracted sizable amounts of money that otherwise might have been placed in bank deposits
* The decline in the deposit-to-GDP ratio since the late 1980s can be attributed to a number of factors, including mutual fund growth and securitization
* The availability of finance for residential, consumer, and business borrowers could be disproportionally affected by the movement of funds out of bank deposits and into mutual funds
* Residential finance has been extensively securitized, with banks and thrifts now providing indirect financing through mortgage-backed securities
* Consumer credit is still largely provided by commercial banks, but some automobile loans and credit card receivables have been securitized
* Corporate financing has been shifting from bank loans to securities issuance, with mutual funds being major purchasers of corporate securities

</summary>

<summary>

• The Public Health Security and Bioterrorism Preparedness and Response Act of 2002 requires specific activities related to bioterrorism preparedness and response, including improving coordination and planning for public health emergencies, developing priority countermeasures, and enhancing state, local, and hospital preparedness and response.
• The Act calls for the establishment of integrated public health alert communications and surveillance networks among federal, state, and local public health officials, laboratories, hospitals, and other entities. These networks are intended to allow for secure and timely sharing of essential information concerning bioterrorism and other public health emergencies.
• Since fiscal year 2002, HHS has funded over $3.7 billion for public health preparedness efforts through grants administered by CDC and just over $1 billion for hospital preparedness grants administered by the Health Resources and Services Administration.
• The funding guidance provided by HHS to state and local governments calls for improvements in seven key areas: preparedness planning and readiness assessment, surveillance and epidemiology capacity, laboratory capacity for handling biological and chemical agents, health alert network/communication and IT, risk communication and health information dissemination, and education and training.

</summary>

• The Act requires the Secretary of HHS to establish an integrated system or systems of public health alert communications and surveillance networks among federal, state, and local public health officials, laboratories, hospitals, and other entities.
• These networks are intended to allow for secure and timely sharing of essential information concerning bioterrorism and other public health emergencies, as well as recommended methods for responding to such an attack or emergency.
• HHS has funded over $3.7 billion for public health preparedness efforts since fiscal year 2002, with over $2.7 billion going towards grants administered by CDC and over $1 billion for hospital preparedness grants administered by the Health Resources and Services Administration.
• The funding guidance provided by HHS to state and local governments calls for improvements in seven key areas: preparedness planning and readiness assessment, surveillance and epidemiology capacity, laboratory capacity for handling biological and chemical agents, health alert network/communication and IT, risk communication and health information dissemination, and education and training.

* Employers have made changes to pension and benefit offerings for both nonbargaining and collectively bargained employees over the last decade.
	+ 81% of responding sponsors modified formulas of one or more DB plans.
	+ 52% of sponsors with plans for nonbargaining unit employees converted traditional plans to cash balance or hybrid arrangements.
	+ 58% of sponsors with plans for collective-bargaining employees reported generally increasing the generosity of their DB plan formulas.
	+ 21% of sponsors with collectively bargained plans reported converting traditional plans to cash balance plans.
	+ Reasons for changes included unpredictability of DB plan funding requirements and global or domestic competitive pressures.
* Future changes may include adding or expanding automatic enrollment features to DC plans, changing investment policies for DB plans, and freezing DB plans for new participants.
	+ 50% of respondents indicated that adding or expanding automatic enrollment features to DC plans was likely or very likely.
	+ 43% indicated that PPA played a major role in this decision.
	+ 45% indicated that changing the investment policy for at least one DB plan to increase the portion of the plan’s portfolio invested in fixed income assets was likely or very likely.
	+ 21% indicated that FASB played a major or moderate role in this decision.
	+ Most respondents did not indicate that recent legislation or account rule changes significantly influenced their decisions on benefit offerings.
	+ Among the minority of firms that reported they were likely to freeze at least one DB plan for new participants only, most indicated that PPA played a role in this decision.
	+ Similarly, while only a few firms indicated that it was likely they would replace a DB plan with a 401(k)-style DC plan, most of these firms also indicated that both PPA and FASB played a role in that decision.
