• Global population is getting older, increasing the trend of aging [1, 2]
• Aging is defined as decreased ability to resist cellular stresses or insults [3, 4]
• Aging is a significant cardiovascular risk factor, leading to increased prevalence of clinical and subclinical cardiovascular diseases [3, 4]
• Endothelium plays a crucial role in adjusting vascular function and is susceptible to aging [5]
• Mechanisms of endothelial aging include oxidative stress and subsequent inflammation [6]
• Exercise can improve endothelial function by boosting antioxidative and anti-inflammatory mechanisms [6]
• Age-related structural changes in endothelium and increased production of reactive oxygen species contribute to endothelial dysfunction [7]

• Age-related structural changes in endothelium include increases in adhesion molecules, permeability, sensitivity to apoptotic stimuli, and decreases in angiogenic and regenerative capacities [43, 44]
• Reactive oxygen species (ROS) and reactive nitrogen species (RNS) are products of normal cellular metabolism but can interfere with endothelial function [47, 5558]
• Superoxide anions and cyclooxygenase (COX) and NADPH oxidase are central to ROS production [47, 5558]
• Peroxynitrite, a product of the reaction between superoxide and nitric oxide (NO), alters the function of biomolecules and decreases NO bioavailability [53, 54]
• Antioxidant defense mechanisms, both enzymatic and nonenzymatic, act synergistically to defend the body from free radical-induced damage [43, 44]
</summary>

<summary>
• Axillary lymph node status is a crucial prognostic factor in breast carcinoma.
• The American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) and International Union Against Cancer (UICC) classify nodal disease based on the number of axillary metastatic lymph nodes.
• Studies suggest that the lymph node ratio (LNR), which is the ratio of metastatic lymph nodes to total removed lymph nodes, provides more useful prognostic information than nodal disease classification.
• The LNR threshold value separating patients into low and high-risk groups varies depending on the study and patient population.
• In a study of breast carcinoma patients with 13 axillary metastatic lymph nodes, patients with higher LNR had significantly worse prognosis than those with lower LNR.
• Axillary radiotherapy is recommended for patients with high LNR in certain patient groups.
• LNR is an independent prognostic factor for disease-free survival (DFS), locoregional recurrence-free survival (LRFS), and distant metastasis-free survival (DMFS).
</summary>

• Axillary lymph node status is a significant prognostic factor in breast carcinoma.
  • The AJCC and UICC classify nodal disease based on the number of axillary metastatic lymph nodes.
  • Studies suggest that the lymph node ratio (LNR) provides more useful prognostic information than nodal disease classification.
  • The LNR threshold value separating patients into low and high-risk groups varies depending on the study and patient population.

<summary>

- Non-native biological invaders have caused significant damage to ecosystems for centuries, with examples including the phylloxera and chestnut blight.
- Charles Elton's 1958 book "The Ecology of Invasions by Animals and Plants" did not inspire a major research thrust or public response to invasions.
- In the mid-1980s, an international project by the Scientific Committee on Problems of the Environment (SCOPE) led to a surge of research on invasions, recognizing them as a major global environmental change.
- Research on invasions has focused on how introduced species impact native species at various levels, including population and community, as well as ecosystem processes.
- A new focus in invasion biology is on genetics and evolution, revealing stealth impacts of invaders through hybridization and introgression with native species.
- Impacts of invasions are more varied and widespread than previously thought, with examples including changes to nutrient cycles and the creation of new, more invasive species.
- Critics of invasion biology and management have raised objections, including the idea that problems are overblown, the belief that invasions increase native biodiversity, xenophobia, the belief that it's a hopeless battle, and concerns about inhumane methods used to combat invasions.
- Despite these criticisms, it is possible to prevent and mitigate the impacts of invasions through biosecurity, early detection, and eradication or containment efforts.
- Some argue for abandoning traditional restoration ecology in favor of novel ecosystems, but this is not a new or well-defined concept, and restoration ecology aims to re-establish historical trajectories before anthropogenic influences.

</summary>

- Non-native biological invaders have caused significant damage to ecosystems for centuries, with examples including the phylloxera and chestnut blight.
  * Phylloxera destroyed grapevines and devastated the wine industry in Europe in the 1860s.
  * Chestnut blight entered North America in the early 20th century and virtually eliminated a dominant tree species.

• The mass was well circumscribed and homogeneously enhancing on imaging.
• The patient was asymptomatic with no dry eye or nasal irritation.

• The patient decided to pursue stereotactic radiotherapy (SRT) as treatment due to the benign histology, her young age, and potential radiation sensitivity from her MS background.

• Nasopharyngeal bursitis originates from the area of communication between the notochord and the foregut (pharyngeal endoderm).
• Two types of nasopharyngeal bursitis: cystic and crust.
• Cystic type: orifice is obstructed, causing postnasal discharge, throat irritation, and cough.
• Crust type: orifice is not obstructed, causing crust shedding, retching, and fetid postnasal discharge.
• Diagnosis: endoscopic examination of nasopharynx and radiologic investigation.
• Treatment: surgical disruption of the bursa with electrocauterization.
• Incidence: less than 1% of all rhinitis patients, equal incidence of cystic and crust types.

• Embryonic development: notochord formation and invaginated connection in nasopharynx.
• Symptoms: inflammation or cystic/abscess formation, shedding crusts, and occipital pain.
• Differential diagnosis: nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
• Histology: tornwaldt's cyst vs. retention lymphoid cyst, reactive lymphoid mucosa with necrotic tissue.
</summary>

- Pregnant women with toxoplasmosis can cause congenital toxoplasmosis in the fetus, leading to various clinical manifestations, including seizures.
- Seizures are a common presenting symptom in patients with congenital toxoplasmosis and central nervous system (CNS) involvement.
- A 34-year-old Arabian female presented with medically intractable seizures, hydrocephalus, and chorioretinitis, consistent with congenital toxoplasmosis.
- Her seizures were intractable, and she underwent a neurological examination, ophthalmologic evaluation, and various diagnostic tests.
- Brain imaging revealed multifocal parenchymal calcifications, hippocampal sclerosis (HS), and amygdala hypertrophy, consistent with congenital toxoplasmosis.
- Video-EEG monitoring showed complex partial seizures (CPS) and secondary generalized tonic-clonic seizures (GTCS), with psychic aura and ictal hyperperfusion in the left mesial temporal areas.
- The patient underwent a Wada test, revealing right hemisphere language and memory dominance, predictive of a good outcome after left anteromesial temporal resection.
- Given the medically intractable seizures and epileptogenic focus in the left temporal lobe, epilepsy surgery with left anteromesial temporal resection was performed.
- The association of congenital toxoplasmosis with mesial temporal lobe epilepsy is poorly reported, and careful prenatal and neonatal monitoring is necessary in Korea due to the increasing prevalence of toxoplasmosis.

• Four and a half years after surgery, enhanced CT imaging showed no residual tumor, and the patient had no clinical evidence of tumor recurrence or postoperative dysfunction

• The study aimed to evaluate the relationship between sedentary behavior and habitual physical activity with visceral adiposity (vat) and liver fat in adults with overweight/obesity.
• No relationship was observed between objectively measured physical inactivity and raised liver fat. Instead, a weak positive association was found between vat volume and time spent in moderate activity.
• Traditional risk factors such as waist circumference, sex, and age were associated with vat and ihl.
• The inclusion of objectively measured levels of moderate activity and sedentary behavior did not improve the potency of traditional risk factors for predicting liver fat concentration or level of visceral adiposity.
• Regular structured physical activity (exercise training) is known to reduce vat and ihl, and current physical activity guidelines advocate structured exercise for health benefits.
• Increasing incidental activity is important for increasing total daily energy expenditure, but there is an established dose potency of structured exercise for cardiovascular and metabolic health risk variables.
• High levels of cardiorespiratory fitness are a characteristic of metabolically healthy obesity, and low cardiorespiratory fitness is an independent predictor of all-cause and cardiovascular disease mortality.
• The emphasis for behavior change in this population should be on adopting and adhering to structured exercise programs, with consideration given to individual barriers to participation and exercise preferences.
• The detrimental effects of increased sedentary behavior and sitting time are well-understood, but this study suggests that a direct link between unstructured, objectively measured levels of physical activity and sedentariness and levels of metabolically risky fat depots is insignificant.

* Subclinical hypothyroidism (SCH) is a common disorder characterized by elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels with normal free thyroxine (FT4) levels, representing early, mild thyroid failure.
	+ Prevalence ranges from 4% to 20% in adults, with women, elderly people, and iodine-sufficient populations being affected more often.
	+ Causes include chronic autoimmune thyroiditis (Hashimoto's thyroiditis) and inadequate thyroid hormone supplementation.
	+ Controversies surround the definition, clinical significance, and optimal treatment of SCH.
* SCH is associated with increased risks of cardiovascular (CV) diseases and metabolic syndrome (METS).
	+ Higher TSH levels are linked to increased body weight, blood pressure, and altered lipid levels.
	+ Elevated TSH levels are inversely associated with all-cause mortality but positively associated with CV mortality.
	+ SCH patients exhibit enhanced inflammatory activity, increased vascular stiffness, and endothelial dysfunction.
	+ SCH is associated with a modest increase in the risks of CV diseases and mortality, particularly in subjects with higher TSH levels.
	+ Elevated FT4 and FT3 levels within the normal range are inversely associated with all-cause and cancer mortality in euthyroid individuals.

- *Clostridium difficile (C. difficile) is a leading cause of antibiotic-associated diarrhea (CDAD).
  *Disruption of normal intestinal flora allows C. difficile to flourish and release toxins A and B.

- *Enzyme immunoassay (EIA) kits are widely used for CDAD diagnosis, but their sensitivity for detecting toxins A and B is low.
  *Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and cytotoxigenic culture have higher detection sensitivities.

- *Patients with toxin-negative stool may be overlooked for treatment and infection countermeasures.
  *Symptomatic patients are identified based on bowel movement status and inflammation markers.

- *The present study investigated patients with gdh-positive and toxin-negative stool specimens.
  *Patient characteristics, diarrhea duration, antibiotics usage, and severity were compared among three groups.

- *Findings showed that diarrhea duration was significantly shorter in patients with toxin-negative stool specimens compared to those with toxin-positive specimens.
  *However, patients with toxin-negative stool but toxin-positive isolates had shorter diarrhea duration than those with toxin-positive stool.

- *EIA directly measures toxin proteins in stool and has a high positive predictive value.
  *PCR detects the presence of bacteria with toxin genes, but patients identified as toxin-positive on PCR may include carriers with diarrhea due to other causes.
</summary>

- The Dream Trial was a large, international study designed to determine if ramipril and/or rosiglitazone could prevent or delay type 2 diabetes in people with IGF or IGT.
  * 5,269 participants with IGF, IGT, or both were recruited and randomized to either ramipril and/or rosiglitazone using a two-by-two factorial design.
  * Followed for a median of 3 years after randomization.
- The primary outcome variable was change in -cell function over the course of follow-up.
  * Assessed using two measures: the insulinogenic index (IGI) and proinsulin (PI) concentration.
  * IGI defined as (30-min insulin / fasting insulin) / (30-min glucose / fasting glucose).

- Participants had OGTTs at baseline, 2 years, and the end of the study, with blood samples drawn fasting and 30 and 120 min after the glucose challenge.
  * Substudy of 982 Dream Trial participants attending Canadian study centers.
- Statistical analyses conducted using SAS version 9.1, with p values < 0.05 considered statistically significant.
  * Distributions of continuous variables assessed for normality, and transformations used as appropriate.

- Rosiglitazone significantly improved -cell function over time as measured by IGI and reduced PI concentrations.
  * Increases in IGI/IR and reductions in PI/C by 86% and 42%, respectively.
  * Effects consistent across glucose tolerance subgroups.
  * Mechanisms responsible for improvements not fully understood, but may include reduction in insulin resistance, amelioration of lipotoxicity, glucotoxicity, and inflammation, and maintenance of -cell proliferation.

- Biological scaffold materials derived from dermis, pericardium, and small intestine submucosa have been used for soft tissue repair applications due to their rapid revascularization and clearance of bacteria in clean or contaminated settings.
- Dermis, pericardium, and small intestine submucosa scaffolds are particularly useful in damage control situations, such as abdominal wall defects, to protect the abdominal contents until granulation tissue forms and a skin graft can be applied.
- Dexon and Vicryl are early designs of absorbable polymer scaffolds, but they lose mechanical strength and are resorbed fairly quickly, making them less than ideal for hernia repair applications.
- Gore Bio-A, Tigr Matrix, and Phasix Mesh are more recent absorbable scaffold designs that utilize long-lasting polymers that degrade more slowly.
- Gore Bio-A is a copolymer of poly(glycolide : trimethylene carbonate) that degrades in vivo through both hydrolytic and enzymatic mechanisms and is fully resorbed within approximately 180 days. It has been utilized in various clinical applications with promising outcomes.
- Tigr Matrix is a knitted mesh made of two fibers with different resorption rates. The first fiber, a copolymer of polyglycolide, polylactide, and polytrimethylene carbonate, loses substantial mechanical strength in the first 14 days and is fully resorbed in approximately 120 days. The second fiber, a copolymer of polylactide and polytrimethylene carbonate, retains its mechanical strength longer and is fully resorbed in approximately 1095 days.
- Phasix Mesh is a fully resorbable polymer monofilament of p4hb that is knitted into a flat sheet configuration. It has been evaluated in a porcine model for hernia repair applications and demonstrated similar mechanical properties, resorption profile, and histological characteristics to the native abdominal wall.
- Phasix Mesh and p4hb Plug repairs demonstrated significantly greater burst strength and relative stiffness compared to the native abdominal wall at all time points, indicating that the p4hb material

<summary>

- The text discusses the implementation and diagnostic accuracy of the Xpert Vana / Vanb assay in detecting Vancomycin-Resistant Enterococci (VRE) in Denmark.
  * The study compares the assay with the culture-based method using overnight enrichment and selective chromogenic agar.
  * The Xpert Vana / Vanb assay provides results within an hour, while the culture-based method takes several days.

- The diagnostic accuracy of the Xpert Vana / Vanb assay was evaluated using culture results and patient follow-up samples as a reference standard.
  * The sensitivity of the assay was 87.1% (95% CI 82.1%-92.2%) and the specificity was 99.7% (95% CI 99.3%-100%).
  * One previous study reported lower sensitivity and specificity, but the large proportion (22.3%) of false-positive vanb PCR results is in accordance with previous studies.

- The implementation of the Xpert Vana / Vanb assay led to significant time and cost savings, as well as faster outbreak declaration and implementation of additional infection control measures.
  * The study calculated saved isolation days and saved transmission risk days as a consequence of earlier suspension or implementation of isolation measures.
  * Earlier available positive screening results from roommates also led to faster outbreak declaration and additional infection control measures.

- The strengths of the study include the large sample size and the prospective and thorough comparison of the Xpert Vana / Vanb assay with the selective culture method, including further investigation of discordant samples.
  * However, a systematic study of genetically diverse strains would be necessary to conclude on the generalizability of the results.
</summary>

<summary>
• Study aimed to compare effects of ru28318 (ru), captopril (capt), and losartan (los) on ischemia/reperfusion (i/r)-induced cardiac dysfunction in normal and diabetic rats
• Diabetes was induced by a single intraperitoneal injection of streptozotocin (stz)
• Ru resulted in the most rapid recovery in cf within the first 10 min of reperfusion for cf when given before ischemia and in + dp / dt and pmax when administered after ischemia in control hearts
• Cap + los therapy given before ischemia in diabetic hearts resulted in a very rapid improvement in pmax and cf within the first 10 min of reperfusion
• Ru + capt and triple therapy given before ischemia to diabetic hearts resulted in the most rapid recovery in + dp / dt
• Ru + los yielded the most rapid recovery in lvedp when given before ischemia in nondiabetic hearts
• Capt + los double therapy yielded the best improvement of around 30% in lvedp when given either before or after ischemia
• Los given alone in diabetic hearts was relatively more effective at improving lvedp than in nondiabetic control hearts
• Drug treatments significantly improved function when administered either before or after ischemia, with triple therapy being better than double therapy which in turn was more effective than single therapies
• The study suggests that optimal usage of drugs alone or in combination may require selection based on several criteria including the normal versus pathological state, prevention or treatment strategy, specific cardiac parameter, and optimal rate of cardiac function recovery
</summary>

<summary>

* Modern nasal surgery aims to improve cosmetic appearance and natural functions of the nose
* Acoustic rhinometry (AR) is commonly used to measure nasal cavity geometry for respiratory medicine
* AR demonstrates a close correlation between measured and calculated nasal airway areas
* Factors influencing nose geometry include race, age, sex, height, weight, and smoking habit
* Study evaluates changes in nasal dimensions of healthy Iranian volunteers after cosmetic rhinoplasty using AR
* Measurements taken before and after surgery for length, minimal cross-sectional area (MCA), and volume of each nasal cavity
* No complaints of breathing problems or dissatisfaction reported by cases
* Significant changes observed in MCA1, MCA2, and d1, with reductions in d1 and increases in MCA1 and MCA2

* Preoperative and postoperative geometric values with and without decongestant
* Right and left d1, bilateral d2, and MCA2 did not change significantly
* Bilateral d1 and both MCA2 decreased significantly with decongestant, while MCA1 increased significantly
* Cases with septoplasty experienced more increase in MCA1 and less constriction in MCA2
* Double osteotomy positively affects nose function by increasing MCA1
* Placing a columellar strut beneficial for patients in both groups with and without septoplasty
* AR provides objective documentation and diagnosis for nasal airway blockage
* AR suitable for evaluation of nasal cavity in cases of septoplasty and turbinoplasty

</summary>

<summary>
• Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of mortality in economically developed nations, accounting for about 30% of all deaths.
• Research focuses on preventing early development of cardiovascular risk factors such as atherosclerosis, hypertension, dyslipidemia, chronic inflammation, and insulin resistance.
• N-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (n-3 PUFAs) have beneficial effects on cardiovascular health, including lipid lowering, anti-inflammatory, antithrombotic, and antiarrhythmogenic effects.
• Low-grade chronic inflammation is a significant contributor to atherosclerosis and coronary heart disease.
• Endothelial cells synthesize and release nitric oxide and prostaglandins to maintain a balance between pro- and anti-inflammatory molecules.
• In the presence of atherosclerosis, this balance is disrupted, leading to an increase in proinflammatory cytokines and further progression of the disease.
• Proinflammatory cytokines can induce oxidative stress by enhancing the production of reactive oxygen species by monocytes, macrophages, and leukocytes.
• PUFAs and their eicosanoid derivatives may play a significant role in modulating the inflammatory response.
• Humans cannot synthesize linoleic acid (LA) and α-linolenic acid (ALA), which are essential fatty acids and precursors to the n-6 and n-3 series of fatty acids, respectively.
• Fish is the primary source of long-chain n-3 PUFAs, while plant sources such as seeds and nuts contain ALA, which is limited in its conversion to long-chain n-3 PUFAs.
</summary>

<summary>
• N-3 PUFAs have pleiotropic effects on cardiovascular health by modulating diverse target mechanisms involved in cardiovascular disease development.
• The GISSI-Prevenzione trial demonstrated that supplementation with 850 mg/day of long-chain n-3 PUFAs decreased the risk of mortality, nonfatal myocardial infarction

<summary>
• Rudolf Virchow, a 19th century pathologist, proposed that cancer arises from chronically inflamed cells
• Gastric cancer is linked to chronic inflammation, particularly atrophic gastritis and hypochlorhydria
• Pelayo Correa, a Colombian pathologist, devoted his career to understanding gastric cancer's etiology
• Correa hypothesized a stepwise process from chronic atrophic gastritis to intestinal metaplasia and cancer
• Initial changes occur in the first decade of life, when h pylori colonization occurs
• Correa initially thought environmental factors, such as diet, were responsible for promoting this progression
• In the 1980s, Correa discussed a possible role for campylobacter pylori in gastric cancer
• Robin Warren and Barry Marshall discovered h pylori in the late 1970s and showed it causes gastritis and ulcer disease
• H pylori is now known to be a major risk factor for gastric cancer, with a strong association between infection and intestinal-type cancers
</summary>

<summary>
• Study compared functional and anatomical outcomes of bevacizumab and ranibizumab treatment for neovascular age-related macular degeneration (AMD) in Turkish patients
• Both groups showed significant improvements in mean best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) and central retinal thickness (CRT) compared to baseline at every time point
• No statistically significant difference in change in BCVA or CRT between the two groups at any time point
• Similar injection numbers and mild complications in both groups
• Previous studies have reported similar improvements in visual and anatomical outcomes for bevacizumab and ranibizumab

• CATT study reported similar efficacy and safety of both drugs at 1 year, with no significant difference in visual acuity, anatomical outcomes, or injection numbers
• At month 12, as-needed bevacizumab was equivalent to as-needed ranibizumab with similar gains in visual acuity and significant decreases in CRT
• Two-year results showed greater mean gain in visual acuity in monthly groups than as-needed groups
• Safety concerns include a higher rate of serious adverse events in bevacizumab groups, but no statistically significant difference
• Ongoing debate about safety issues of bevacizumab and ranibizumab
</summary>

<summary>

- Preeclampsia (PE) is a leading cause of maternal and neonatal morbidity and mortality, affecting 25% of pregnancies.
  * Classically diagnosed by proteinuria, but several studies question its significance as a predictor of adverse outcomes.
  * Hypoalbuminemia may serve as an indicator of PE severity.

- Hypoalbuminemia results from systemic small vessel spasm, increased angiotensin secretion, and damaged vascular endothelial cells.
  * Leads to intravascular dehydration, which can accelerate intravascular lesions and contribute to HELLP syndrome and acute fatty liver of pregnancy.
  * Reduction of hepatic blood flow due to albumin production also observed in early pregnancy.

- Study aimed to evaluate maternal and perinatal outcomes in women with PE based on albumin levels (25 g/l and <25 g/l).
  * 299 women enrolled between January 2014 and June 2015.
  * Exclusion criteria: kidney diseases, preexisting proteinuria, essential hypertension, autoimmune diseases, diabetes, twin pregnancies.

- Maternal outcomes evaluated: delivery mode, eclampsia, HELLP syndrome, hypertension, abnormal liver function, abnormal renal function, ascites, oligohydramnios, thrombocytopenia, and abruptio placenta.
  * Complex cases diagnosed by trial management team.

- Neonatal outcomes included perinatal deaths, preterm birth, neonatal asphyxia, and fetal growth restriction.
  * Birth weight also assessed.

- Comparisons of continuous and categorical variables between groups used t-test, Mann-Whitney test, chi-square test, and Fisher's exact test.
  * Univariate logistic regression used to analyze associations between severe hypoproteinemia PE and poor maternal and neonatal outcomes.
</summary>

- Women with severe hypoproteinemia PE (shp) were delivered earlier, had higher cesarean section rates, more severe hypertension, and more frequent abnormal liver

• Avastin (bevacizumab), a humanized monoclonal antibody targeting vegf-a, has been successful in treating various human cancers, including colorectal, lung, and renal cell carcinoma.
• Limitations of anti-angiogenic treatments, such as resistance and pre-existing refractoriness, have been highlighted by the recent withdrawal of avastin for breast cancer treatment in the US.
• Alternative ligands for vegf receptors, such as vegf-c and vegf-d, and other angiogenic factors from distinct growth factor families are potential candidates for promoting resistance to avastin.
• Pigf, a ligand for vegfr-1, may modulate the effect of vegf-a and play a dual role in cancer as a stimulator of angiogenesis and a promoter of tumor cell proliferation.
• Other mechanisms, such as vascular mimicry, endothelial precursor cells, and altered tumor metabolism, may contribute to the development of resistance to anti-angiogenic treatments.
</summary>

<summary>
• Malaria is still a significant public health concern in Iran, particularly in the south and southeast regions.
• Implementation of control measures has led to a substantial reduction of malaria incidence in Iran, with cases decreasing from 11,460 in 2008 to 3,239 in 2011.
• In Iran, Plasmodium vivax is the most common cause of malaria cases, while Plasmodium falciparum accounts for a smaller percentage.
• Iran entered the malaria pre-elimination program in 2009 and has implemented prevention strategies, active case detection, and timely treatment in endemic areas.
• Active surveillance using precise laboratory methods is crucial for early recognition of all parasite carriers, particularly those with asymptomatic infections.
• Asymptomatic malaria infections have been described in hyper-endemic regions, and their prevalence is important to determine for effective elimination strategies.
• Accurate detection methods, such as nested-PCR, are essential for finding all carriers, particularly those without clinical symptoms.
</summary>

<summary>
• Light microscopy of Giemsa-stained thick and thin blood smears is the standard laboratory method for malaria diagnosis, but it has limitations.
• Chromatographic rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs) are used in remote settings and as a complementary method for confirming parasite-infected cases.
• Nested-PCR is a highly sensitive method for malaria detection, particularly in sub-clinical parasitemia levels.
• The present study aimed to detect low parasite and asymptomatic malaria infections using microscopy, RDT, and nested-PCR in a low transmission region of Bagh-e Malek in Minab District, Hormozgan Province.
• The study was a cross-sectional survey of 200 healthy volunteers from Bagh-e Malek, a lowland area with a higher rate of malaria transmission.
• The study found that 1.5% of participants had asymptomatic P. vivax infections that were not detected by microscopy or RDT.

- The text discusses the use of machine learning algorithms, specifically Bayesian belief networks (BBNs), to identify promising biomarkers for immune response to vaccine therapies in complex data sets.
- The study involved sera samples collected from three separate trials: one using androgen deprivation therapy (ADT), one using a viral vaccine (Psav), and one using a plasmid DNA vaccine (Papv).
- Igg responses to individual antigens were detected and associated with specific treatments, suggesting that the generation of immune responses to off-target antigens might be associated with other measures of immune response or clinical outcome.
- The findings demonstrate that immune-active therapies, including ADT, elicit igg responses to individual prostate-associated antigens, and that these responses are most evident at a later time point. Using a ml-bbn model, a cohort of antigens was prioritized that were most associated with psa decline, suggesting that models could be developed to assist in the detection of therapeutic immune responses.

</summary>

• The study explores the use of piezoelectric materials and the converse piezoelectric effect to mechanically stimulate bone growth at the implant interface
• Key findings include:
  • Higher bone area around actuators compared to static controls (39.91% vs. 27.20%)
  • Increased new bone formation around actuators (64.89% vs. 31.72%)
  • Significantly higher mineral apposition rate around actuated films (4.44 m/day vs. 2.70 m/day)
• Challenges and considerations for future research include:
  • Developing a more biocompatible material for the implants
  • Investigating potential effects of coating damage and electrical current on bone growth
</summary>

<summary>
• Study conducted in the department of oral medicine and radiology and a cancer centre
• Sample consisted of 90 individuals: 60 oscc patients and 30 healthy controls
• Exclusion criteria: individuals with other malignancies, liver disease, tuberculosis, diabetes mellitus, cardiovascular diseases, or chronic systemic diseases
• Serum l-fucose levels estimated using clinical chemistry autoanalyzer based on Winzler method
• Independent samples t-test used to compare mean values between genders, one-way anova used for three or more groups
• Mean value of serum l-fucose levels in oscc patients was 10.85 mg/dl, in healthy controls was 3.47 mg/dl (p<0.001)
• Serum l-fucose levels increased with cancer stages: 8.13 mg/dl (stage I), 9.18 mg/dl (stage II), 10.53 mg/dl (stage III), 11.59 mg/dl (stage IV)
• Negative correlation between serum fucose levels and histopathological tumor differentiation
</summary>

• Serum l-fucose is a monosaccharide and essential sugar for normal cell-to-cell communication
• Lack of hydroxyl group on carbon at position 6 and l-configuration distinguish fucose from other sugars
• Increased fucosylation is associated with elevated fuct activity and cancer progression
• Fucosylation of glycoproteins is important for cell-cell interactions, cell adhesion, and malignant transformation
• Elevated serum fucose levels can be a promising approach for early detection, diagnosis, and prognosis of various cancers, including oral carcinoma
• Non-specific increase in serum fucose levels observed in other pathological states and malignancies
• Further investigation required to confirm serum l-fucose as an effective tumor marker in oral cancer diagnosis and management.

- LCN2 mice were generated by gene targeting in embryonic stem cells and backcrossed onto the b6 background for 10 generations.
- Heterozygous mating scheme was used to generate wild-type and LCN2 mice for experiments.
- Animals were housed in a specific pathogen-free facility and handled following NIH guidelines.
- Age-matched male wild-type and LCN2 mice were fed either an HFD or regular chow diet for 12 weeks or 30 weeks, respectively.
- LCN2 mice on an HFD gained more body weight and increased adiposity, with higher weights of white and brown fat pads and organs such as liver, heart, kidney, and spleen.
- LCN2 mice on an HFD also showed larger adipose cells in fat-cell size distributions.
- Food intake and energy expenditure were not significantly different between RCD-fed wild-type and LCN2 mice at 18 weeks of age.
- LCN2 mice displayed cold sensitivity and could not survive when exposed to 4°C for >10 hours.
- Cold exposure caused a 10-fold increase in LCN2 gene expression in adipose tissue in wild-type mice, but not in LCN2 mice.
- LCN2 deficiency impaired adaptive thermogenesis and increased the susceptibility of LCN2 mice to HFD-induced obesity and insulin resistance.

</summary>

<summary>

- The study aimed to investigate the effect of weight bearing on the development of non-traumatic osteonecrosis of the femoral head in rats.
  * Using a non-traumatic animal model, rats were given LPS and methylprednisolone to induce osteonecrosis.
  * Hindlimb unloading was employed to prevent weight bearing on the hindlimbs.

- The results showed that seven of 11 (63.6%) weight-bearing rats and six of 11 (54.5%) non-weight-bearing rats developed osteonecrosis, with no significant intergroup difference observed.
  * Both groups exhibited similar histopathological features, including the presence of empty lacunae and bone marrow cell necrosis.

- The study confirmed that weight bearing does not contribute to the development of non-traumatic osteonecrosis in rats.
  * The findings may help clarify the pathogenesis of osteonecrosis and devise prevention strategies.
  * However, the model may not be suitable for observing the mechanism of femoral head collapse.

- The study also discussed the limitations of existing quadruped animal models of osteonecrosis and their applicability to understanding the condition in bipedal animals.
  * The rat model may provide insights into the pathogenesis of osteonecrosis but may not be useful for observing the mechanism of femoral head collapse.
</summary>

<summary>

* Nurses' involvement in national policy processes is important due to their large numbers in the global health workforce and their close relationship with patients
* Reasons for nurses' limited participation in policy include lack of awareness, inadequate knowledge and skills, and gender differences
* Strategies to enhance nurses' engagement in policy include assuming formal leadership positions, lobbying and advocacy, and building competencies through education and training
* The study applied a critical theory perspective to examine nurses' involvement in policy processes in Kenya, revealing historical hierarchies and gender-related issues
* The study's findings highlighted the need for policy changes to address hierarchies and domination in the health care system and to establish mechanisms for nurses' views to reach national decision-makers

</summary>

	+ Nurses comprise the majority of the global health care workforce
	+ Work closely with patients and families in various settings
* Reasons for nurses' limited participation in policy
	+ Lack of awareness of policy issues and processes
	+ Inadequate knowledge and skills to contribute
	+ Gender differences in the health care system
* Strategies to enhance nurses' engagement in policy
	+ Assuming formal leadership positions
	+ Lobbying and advocacy through professional organizations
	+ Building competencies through education and training
* Study findings in Kenya
	+ Historical hierarchies and gender-related issues affecting nurses' participation
	+ Need for policy changes to address these issues
	+ Establishing mechanisms for nurses' views to reach national decision-makers
* Critical theory perspective used to examine policy processes
	+ Interrogating historical hierarchies and structures
	+ Examining gender domination and discrimination
* Implications for policy and practice
	+ Addressing hierarchies and domination in the health care system
	+ Establishing mechanisms for nurses' views to reach national decision-makers
	+ Enhancing nurses' competencies to contribute to policy decisions

* UTI is a common problem in infants and young children, with varying frequency, symptoms, and causative organisms depending on age and gender.
* Neonates present with non-specific signs and symptoms, requiring a complete sepsis workup and a 7-14 day course of antibiotics, typically parenteral ampicillin plus an aminoglycoside or a third-generation cephalosporin.
* Recent reports of emerging patterns of resistance toward empirical antibiotics, especially ampicillin, make the early choice of antibiotics a challenging decision.
* Clinical manifestations of UTI in neonates are mostly non-specific and systemic, such as fever, irritability, lethargy, vomiting, growth failure, abnormal urination, and jaundice.
* UTI in newborns could lead to urosepsis or neonatal sepsis, making it often managed as a case of sepsis.
* Most UTIs in infants are caused by gram-negative bacilli, with e. coli being the most prevalent organism causing UTI in all ages, accounting for up to 80% of isolates.
* Other enterobacteriaceae causing UTI in neonates include klebsiella, enterobacter, citrobacter, proteus, providencia, morganella, serratia, and salmonella.
* Gram-positive bacteria like staphylococcus and enterococcus have less been retrieved from neonates with UTI.

<summary>
• Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH) is a group of inherited disorders caused by a deficiency in an adrenal enzyme, leading to altered cortisol and aldosterone secretion.
• The most common variant is 21-hydroxylase deficiency (21-OHD), causing decreased negative feedback to the HPA axis and subsequent hyperplasia of the adrenal gland.
• CAH patients may exhibit white matter changes and temporal lobe structures dysgenesis, as documented in several studies.
• White matter abnormalities include periventricular hyperintensities and cerebellar atrophy, while temporal lobe dysgenesis may result in hippocampal dysplasia and amygdala dysplasia.
</summary>

• White matter changes:
• Periventricular hyperintensities: non-specific signal changes, subclinical or with unremarkable neurological signs.
• Cerebellar atrophy: less common, may be associated with cognitive deficits.

• Temporal lobe structures dysgenesis:
• Hippocampal dysplasia: characterized by distorted anatomy, small volume, and disturbed internal architecture.
• Amygdala dysplasia: smaller than the contralateral side or with increased signal on T2 and FLAIR sequences.

<summary>

• The human genome draft sequence holds great promise for biomedical advances this century.
• Biologists need to navigate the vast genomic data using universal vocabularies and annotate genes.
• Two common ways of annotating genes are through empirical observations and predicted evolutionary relationships.
• Homology-based annotation relies on the identification of protein homologs and their similar functions.
• Homology assignments indicate an approximate direction for future empirical determination of function.
• Domain resources, such as Pfam, SMART, and InterPro, help identify domains and predict protein functions.
• Comparative proteomics and domain studies have contributed to understanding gene evolution and proteome diversity.

</summary>

• Biologists face the challenge of navigating the vast genomic data landscape using universal vocabularies.
• Two common ways of annotating genes are through empirical observations and predicted evolutionary relationships.

• Empirical observations involve characterizing genes experimentally and assigning names and functions.
• Predicted evolutionary relationships involve identifying homologous genes and their functions.

• Homology-based annotation relies on the identification of protein homologs and their similar functions.
• Homology assignments indicate an approximate direction for future empirical determination of function.

• Domain resources, such as Pfam, SMART, and InterPro, help identify domains and predict protein functions.
• Comparative proteomics and domain studies have contributed to understanding gene evolution and proteome diversity.

• Pfam is the widest-ranging lexicon of domain families, predicting at least one domain for more than two-thirds of all entries in the Swiss-Prot protein database.
• SMART focuses on those domains that are widespread and difficult to detect.
• InterPro combines the domain and motif sets of ProSite, Pfam, ProDom, Prints, and SMART in a hierarchical manner.

• Homology assignments are guided by comparisons of HMMs or GPs with protein sequence databases and an upper threshold value for e.
• These procedures have been shown to identify subtle, yet informative, sequence similarities among distant homologs.

• Comparative proteomics and domain studies have demonstrated the power of relating gene content to the evolution of eukaryotic organisms.

<summary>

- Heart rate monitors have been widely used in sports and sports science for the past 25 years.
- Four commercially available systems, Polar Team Pro, Acentas Team Monitoring System, Suunto Pro Team Pack, and Activio Sport System, were tested in a field study.
- The study aimed to compare the systems in terms of operating distance, validity against ECG, and software and hardware quality.
- A total of 12 active people participated in the study, including 10 men from an amateur soccer team and one male and one female subject for validity testing.
- The main test was the measurement of failure ratio during a soccer match, with all players except the goalkeeper wearing chest belts.
- The chest belts' wearing comfort was evaluated using a questionnaire, and the failure ratio was determined based on the percentage of valid data during a 45-minute match.

Sub-points:
- The questionnaire contained five questions about the handling and individual fitting of the chest belts.
- Each question was scored on a six-point scale, with a maximum score of 25 for the whole questionnaire.
- The main field test was the measurement of failure ratio during a soccer match.
- Each deviation or loss of data was subtracted from the maximum score of 100.

- Distance measurement was conducted on an uphill street to reduce possible interference.
- The receiver antenna was placed on the highest elevation of the hill, and the participants were equipped with a GPS device to measure distance.
- The systems were evaluated based on measurement, software, and hardware quality.
- The rating system was set in favor of measurement, with 200 scores for maximal measurement quality and the remaining 300 scores equally divided between hardware and software quality.

Sub-points:
- The measurement sub-categories were evaluated using a ten-stepped visual analogue scale.
- The software and hardware sub-categories were evaluated by an experienced person, except for wearing comfort and failing quota in the field, which were evaluated using a questionnaire.
- The wearing comfort of the chest belts was evaluated using a short anonymous questionnaire.
- The questionnaire contained five questions about the handling and individual fitting of the chest belts.
</summary>

<summary>

- In the 1960s, McCulloch and Till proposed three functional characteristics for defining stem cells: self-renewal, proliferation, and multipotency.
  * Self-renewal: ability to make identical copies of themselves.
  * Proliferation: ability to divide and produce new cells.
  * Multipotency: ability to differentiate into various cell types.
- Stem cells have been identified in the lung, primarily through their role in airway repair.
  * Tracheal basal cells expressing keratin-5 (k5) and keratin-14 (k14) have been identified as stem cell niches.
  * Squamous cell carcinoma is more likely to arise from k5 stem cells.
- Clara cells in middle airways are considered facultative progenitor cells, as they can proliferate and differentiate into various cell types.
  * After injury, clara cells in neuroepithelial bodies (NEB) can independently repopulate the middle airways.
  * Small cell lung carcinomas contain cells expressing cd44 and multidrug resistance 1 (mdr1), potential markers for mid-airway stem cells.
- The hierarchical or cancer stem cell hypothesis suggests that relatively rare, multipotent cells drive tumor growth and heterogeneity.
  * Stem-like cells, with the ability to rapidly proliferate and self-renew, may act as cancer stem cells.
  * Lung cancer stem cells express high levels of anti-apoptotic and drug-resistant proteins, contributing to chemotherapy resistance.
- Recent studies have identified tumor cell subpopulations with stem-like properties, including multidrug resistance, increased telomerase expression, and self-renewal.
  * cd133 cells isolated from human lung cancer specimens exhibit stem-like properties, including indefinite growth in culture and the ability to proliferate into diverse tumors.
  * Patients with lung tumors enriched with cd133 lung cancer stem cells have worse prognosis and increased resistance to cisplatin-based therapies.

<summary>
• Study evaluating the role of urethral plate character in the success of tip urethroplasty for primary anterior penile hypospadias in 100 children
• Divided study population into two groups based on urethral plate width (>8 mm and <8 mm) and three categories based on plate character (flat, cleft, and deeply grooved)
• Found significantly higher incidences of fistula and failed 8 fr calibration in group-b patients with urethral plate width <8 mm
• Recommendation for ideal urethral plate to create neourethra >10 fr in children after midline incision, but a narrow plate <8 mm is inadequate and may cause higher fistula rate due to tension on suture line
</summary>

• Study findings
  • Significantly higher incidences of fistula and failed 8 fr calibration in group-b patients with urethral plate width <8 mm (p=0.004 and p=0.01, respectively)
  • Narrow urethral plate <8 mm inadequate for creating neourethra, leading to tension on suture line and increased fistula formation
  • Modification to midline incision of the plate by extending it beyond the tip of the glans prevents meatal stenosis but only decreases fistula rate and meatal stenosis to <1%

• Recommendations
  • Ideal urethral plate allows creation of neourethra >10 fr in children after midline incision
  • Narrow urethral plate <8 mm may require augmentation with free graft or buccal mucosal graft (BMG) to improve results
  • Use of BMG with tip repair recommended for patients with flat and narrow urethral plates to decrease fistula rate formation and meatal stenosis
  • Tip urethroplasty offers advantages such as preservation and utilization of urethral plate, single suture line, creation of glandular and penile urethra, short operative time, and low complication rate.

- Trichomonas vaginalis (TV) infection is a common curable sexually transmitted infection with approximately 173 million new cases annually.
  * Associated with adverse reproductive health outcomes, including pelvic inflammatory disease, low infant birth weight, and premature delivery.
  * Increases transmission and acquisition of other sexually transmitted diseases, including HIV infection.

- The study was a cross-sectional analysis of behavioral and biological data from a Peruvian cohort enrolled in an HIV/STD prevention trial between 2003 and 2005.
  * Focused on socially marginalized women in low-income neighborhoods in Lima, Trujillo, and Chiclayo.
  * Participants were recruited based on sexual risk behaviors and sociodemographic characteristics.

- Prevalence of TV infection was higher among older women, those with less education, singles, and women reporting unprotected sex with nonsteady partners or multiple sex partners.
  * No association was found between vaginal symptoms and TV infection.
  * Syndromic management of TV may result in both over and under treatment due to the asymptomatic nature of the infection.

- The study highlights the importance of addressing hard-to-reach populations, as they are often underrepresented and represent a high-risk target population for trichomoniasis.
  * Prevalence of trichomoniasis varies widely, with highest rates found in population samples and lower rates in clinical settings.
  * Screening and treatment programs are needed to control the spread of trichomoniasis.

- The study's limitations include a small sample size, potential generalizability issues, and the possibility of selection bias.
  * Selection bias was minimized by the use of standardized interviews and the fact that all epidemiologic information was collected prior to testing.

- The findings support the need for improved disease control activities to reduce adverse reproductive health outcomes associated with trichomoniasis.
  * Further studies are needed to determine if screening and treatment of trichomoniasis will improve reproductive health and birth outcomes.

</summary>

- * Rufinamide is a novel anticonvulsant drug approved for the adjunctive treatment of LGS and partial seizures in children and adults.
  * Structurally unrelated to other anticonvulsants.
  * Mechanism of action involves decreased firing of high frequency sodium-dependent action potentials and prolongation of sodium channel inactivation.
  * Wide spectrum of anticonvulsant effectiveness in animals.

- * Rufinamide has an excellent safety profile, with minimal cognitive side effects and behavioral toxicity at clinically relevant doses.
  * Well absorbed with slow absorption rate and low protein binding.
  * Eliminated primarily via metabolism, with minimal drug-drug interactions.
  * Effective in reducing seizure frequency and improving seizure severity in LGS patients according to clinical trials.

• The study explores the role of chemical sexual signals in interpopulational recognition between five distinct populations of iberian wall lizards in central Spain.
   • Differences in morphology and genetic makeup suggest that these populations might be reproductively isolated.
   • GC-MS analysis revealed interpopulational variations in the composition and proportions of chemical compounds in femoral gland secretions of males.
   • Tongue-flick experiments showed that males and females discriminated by chemosensory cues alone between scents of lizards from different populations.

• Results suggest that male and female lizards could recognize and prefer the scents of individuals from their own population, contributing to reduced gene flow.
   • Interpopulational differences in chemical signals and population recognition abilities suggest the probable existence of reproductive isolation and cryptic speciation between these iberian wall lizard populations.
   • Males from some populations discriminated and maybe preferred scents of females from their own population, potentially indicating cryptic speciation.
   • Females also seemed to discriminate male chemicals between areas but not between populations.
   • Further studies, including mating experiments, are needed to test the hypothesis of cryptic speciation.

• Medline/PubMed is the most frequently used database, with over 5,100 titles and free access
• Controlled vocabulary like Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) helps researchers retrieve information more precisely
• Small details, such as non-standardized author and institution names, make it difficult to find articles and evaluate institutions
• Journals with high impact factors (IFs) are considered more influential in their fields
• Few Brazilian journals have high IFs, but the number has been increasing
• The evaluation of scientific production involves analyzing both quantity and quality, using bibliometric indicators like citations

Sub-points:

- The evaluation of scientific production is complex due to the diversity of fields and research areas
- Smaller units, like university departments or services, can be analyzed more easily when the number of researchers is large
- A raffle system is often used to choose representatives from different functional categories for analysis
- The present investigation focused on the scientific production of full professors at the Universidade de São Paulo's Faculdade de Medicina during 2001-2006

• According to WHO experts, the risk of rubella transmission from mother to fetus is approximately 90% during early pregnancy.
• Congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) is the primary complication of rubella, which affects an estimated 110,000 infants annually in developing countries.
• Vaccination of susceptible individuals or women in reproductive age is the primary means of preventing rubella and CRS.
• The most commonly used rubella vaccine is derived from the ra27/3 virus strain, which induces immunity in 95% of vaccinated persons.
• Studies in various countries, such as Australia, Denmark, and Iran, have shown significant increases in rubella immunity after mass vaccination campaigns.

• In Australia, the rubella vaccination for schoolgirls led to a significant decrease in CRS.
• In Denmark, the vaccination policy was replaced by extensive vaccination with two doses of MMR, resulting in a 96.5% immunity rate.
• In Iran, a study in Kermanshah province showed a significant increase in rubella immunity after mass vaccination, from 80% in 1999 to over 90% in 2006.
• In Iran, the national immunity rate for measles and rubella increased from 73.4% to 98.8% after mass vaccination in 2003.
• Studies in Mashhad, Shahre-Kord, and Hamadan also showed significant increases in rubella immunity after vaccination.

• Western blotting showed disappearance of some bands and persistence of others in post-operative cases.
• Antibodies against proteins of 24 and 39 kDa are useful markers for post-surgical monitoring.

- Mitochondria produce reactive oxygen species (ROS) during oxidative metabolism, which can regulate signaling through posttranslational modification of proteins.
  * Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) is formed from superoxide anion (O2-) by cellular superoxide dismutases (SODs).
  * Oxidation of cysteine thiol groups (SH) by H2O2 results in formation of sulphenic acid (SOH), which quickly forms disulfide (SS) or sulfenyl amide (SN) bonds.
- Mitochondrial ROS (mROS) generation is required for epidermal homeostasis and stem cell differentiation.
  * mROS promote signaling through pathways required for differentiation, including Notch and Wnt--catenin.
  * mROS act as pro-differentiation signals and are key upstream regulators of stem cell fate decisions.
- Mitochondrial metabolism promotes cellular differentiation through various mechanisms.
  * mROS production is required for activation of Notch and Wnt--catenin transcriptional programs.
  * Mitochondrial metabolism provides substrates for histone acetyltransferases and histone demethylases, regulating chromatin structure and gene expression.

* The text discusses the use of amphibian metamorphosis as a model for testing endocrine-disrupting chemicals, focusing on thyroid toxicity and the role of thyroid hormones (THs) in the process.
* Thyroid hormones play a crucial role in amphibian metamorphosis, and their disruption can lead to various morphological changes.
** Thyroid hormones are synthesized in the thyroid gland and secreted into the bloodstream, where they bind to transport proteins like transthyretin (TTR).
** THs are metabolized through various processes, including sulfation, deiodination, and glucuronidation, which can be influenced by environmental contaminants.
* Several studies have investigated the effects of chemicals on TH metabolism in amphibians, including inhibition of thyroidal iodide uptake, suppression of thyroidal peroxidase activity, and interference with TTR binding.
** Chemicals like diethylstilbestrol (DES), phenolic and phenol compounds, pentachlorophenol, and ioxynil have been shown to bind to TTR and alter TH homeostasis.
** The premetamorphic and metamorphic stages of amphibian development are particularly sensitive to TH disruption, and exposure to synthetic thyroid hormone receptor antagonists or agonists can lead to retardation or precocious induction of metamorphosis.
** The sensitivity of amphibians to THs varies during development, and the amount of spontaneously released thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is higher in late prometamorphic and climactic tadpoles.
** Several thyroid disrupting substances, such as perchlorate and polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), have been tested for toxicity using amphibians, and their effects on TH metabolism and development have been documented.
** The amphibian metamorphosis assay (AMA) has been established as a guideline for testing chemicals for thyroid disruption, and it is used by organizations like the OECD and EPA for endocrine screening programs.

<summary>
• Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs: a theory proposing human needs can be represented as a pyramid with fundamental levels at the bottom
• Needs: physiological, safety, belongingness and love, esteem, self-actualization
• Physiological needs: food, sex, safety needs: personal security, financial security, health and well-being
• Safety needs more fundamental than physiological needs, as they can block physiological needs
• Fear and safety needs: fear can make physiological needs underestimated, safety needs can amplify threats and initiate appropriate responses
• Maslow's example: infants prefer predictable routines, fear injustice and inconsistency
• Appraisal theory: emotions result from people's interpretations and explanations of circumstances
• Primary appraisal: faster, automatic process related to fear, secondary appraisal: slower, deliberate process related to anger and coping options
</summary>

• The Patient-Centered Medical Home (PCMH) model is an extension of the Chronic Care Model (CCM) and aims to provide quality, coordinated, and cost-effective care to patients.
• Challenges in implementing the PCMH model include promoting physician buy-in, changing office culture, care coordination, staffing and space allocations, and leveraging electronic medical records (EMRs).
• To become recognized as a PCMH by the National Committee for Quality Assurance (NCQA), a practice must provide documentation of its guidelines for implementation and create its own policies that adhere to PCMH principles.
• Physician buy-in is crucial for a successful transition, but many physicians resist due to a lack of training, misaligned financial incentives, underreimbursement, and time-consuming procedures.
• Team-based care is a key component of the PCMH model, which requires staff to address patient treatment decisions collectively and use previsit huddles to allocate resources and ensure adequate health maintenance.
• Care coordinators or care managers are often hired to perform tasks previously delivered inconsistently or not at all, such as patient follow-ups and patient education. However, their time, salary, responsibilities, and workload are not always defined in the cost or structure of a typical practice.
</summary>

<summary>
• Radical retropubic prostatectomy is the surgical treatment of choice for localized prostate cancer with excellent tumor control and low morbidity, but major long-term morbidity is erectile dysfunction.
• Erectile dysfunction occurs due to injury of cavernosal nerves, which are mainly concentrated laterally to the prostate and referred to as neurovascular bundles.
• Nerve sparing radical retropubic prostatectomy has led to improvements in potency rates, with 16-76% recovery in those with bilateral neurovascular bundle preservation and 0-56% in those with unilateral preservation.
• Recent studies have challenged the traditional knowledge of the neurovascular bundle, proposing that it contains few pelvic splanchnic nerve components and that cavernous nerves are spread beyond it.
• This study aimed to distinguish microscopic features and anatomic navigation of periprostatic nerves using male adult cadavers.

• Number of periprostatic nerve fibers was evenly distributed to dorsal and both lateral areas of the prostate in this study.
• No cord-like neurovascular bundle was observed in any cadaver case.

• Modified nerve-sparing techniques by incising the periprostatic fascia more anteriorly are feasible for saving periprostatic nerves.
• The mean percentage of nerves in the ventral part was 6.7% (range: 4.5-9.4%).

- Glucocorticoids have anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects, but they also play coadjuvant roles in promoting inflammation and Th2-type immunity.
- Perforin deficiency is associated with a selective defect in granulocyte production, which can be corrected by wild-type lymphocyte transfer.
- In the absence of allergen sensitization and challenge, pfp mice have reduced granulocyte numbers both inside and outside of bone marrow compared to wild-type controls.
- Liquid bone marrow cultures showed that il-5 and dexamethasone stimulated eosinopoiesis in wild-type bone marrow but not in pfp bone marrow.
- Semisolid bone marrow cultures showed that perforin-deficient bone marrow progenitors formed fewer colonies and did not respond to dexamethasone.
- Dexamethasone injection increased bone marrow eosinophils and neutrophils in wild-type b6 mice but not in pfp mice.
- The thymus of pfp mice responded to dexamethasone injection as expected, indicating that the lack of responsiveness in pfp bone marrow is not due to a general lack of response to glucocorticoids.
- Transfer of splenic lymphocytes from naive wild-type mice reconstituted the granulopoietic responses to dexamethasone in pfp mice, but different cells may be involved in reconstitution of lineage-specific responses.
- Neutrophils were reduced in bone marrow and blood of pfp mice relative to b6 controls, arguing against reduced numbers in bone marrow being due to increased export to the periphery.
- The lack of appropriate response to gm-csf, both in the absence and in the presence of dexamethasone, predicts that emergency granulopoiesis would be defective in pfp mice and might negatively influence the outcome of sepsis.

</summary>

<summary>

* Extensively studied cell types for cardiac regeneration include embryonic stem cells (ESCs), mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs), skeletal myoblasts, and bone marrow-derived progenitor cells.
* ESCs can be obtained from pre-implantation blastocysts, expanded in vitro, and differentiated into cardiovascular lineages. However, concerns over teratoma formation, graft-versus-host disease, and bioethics have hindered clinical trials.
* Induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) can be generated from adult somatic cells and differentiated into functional cardiovascular lineages. They may provide an unlimited supply of autologous donor cells, but concerns over tumorigenesis and ethical issues remain.
* MSCs can be isolated from bone marrow and adipose tissues, differentiated into cardiomyocytes, and expanded in culture for autologous transplantation. However, their propensity to differentiate into non-cardiac tissues limits their use.
* Skeletal myoblasts can be harvested from muscle biopsies, expanded in culture, and autologously reimplanted. They are less prone to teratoma formation and more resistant to ongoing ischemia, but true cardiomyocyte differentiation has not been observed in vivo.
* Bone marrow-derived mononuclear cells can be mobilized or harvested and differentiated into cardiomyocytes, endothelial cells, and smooth muscle cells in vitro. They can supply paracrine factors with proangiogenic, positive remodeling, and antiapoptotic properties after transplantation.

</summary>

* Cell sources for cardiac regeneration: ESCs, MSCs, skeletal myoblasts, and bone marrow-derived progenitor cells.
** ESCs: Obtained from pre-implantation blastocysts, expanded in vitro, differentiated into cardiovascular lineages, but concerns over teratoma formation, graft-versus-host disease, and bioethics.
** iPSCs: Generated from adult somatic cells, differentiated into functional cardiovascular line

<summary>

• Polyhalite is a mineral commonly found in sedimentary evaporite successions and rare volcanic successions.
• It was first described in Austria in 1818 by German chemist Stromeyer.
• Polyhalite is associated with halite, anhydrite, glauberite, carnallite, kieserite, langbeinite, vanthoffite, chlorides, and sulphides.
• Its crystal structure was first determined in samples from Altaussee, Austria, and later confirmed.
• Polyhalite can be synthesised under laboratory conditions by reacting gypsum with appropriate solutions in the ternary system K2SO4MgSO4H2O at temperatures above 70°C.
• The dehydration temperature of polyhalite starts at 255°C and reaches a maximum of 343°C.
• Substitution of divalent cations by other elements significantly changes dehydration reactions to higher or lower temperatures.
• Polyhalite most commonly forms early diagenetically by brine-back reactions of K Mg SO4 brine with earlier formed gypsum, anhydrite, or glauberite after prolonged contact.
• It is stable between room temperature and 255-343°C and is of interest for absolute age dating due to its potassium content.

</summary>

* The study was conducted in RS Pura health block of Jammu district in Jammu and Kashmir state to assess community perception, beliefs, and attitudes (KAP) regarding malaria among inhabitants.
* Key findings included:
	+ A majority (76.35%) of the study participants had knowledge of malaria symptoms, and a majority of them knew that malaria could be both prevented (90.5%) and cured (93.2%).
	+ The majority (92.5%) considered malaria to be a serious health problem, and more than two-thirds would consult a doctor in case of a child's illness.
	+ The overall attitude toward the use of bed nets and vector control programs was positive.
	+ Preventive measures included avoiding collections of stagnant water and indoor spraying.
	+ The main source of information was television (tv)/newspaper (68.2%).
	+ Knowledge regarding causation, cure, and prevention were high, but knowledge that malaria can be fatal was lower.
	+ The respondents' attitude toward malaria was reflected in their labeling it as a serious health problem, and the majority consulted a doctor in case of a child being febrile.
	+ Despite excellent knowledge, preventive measures were not always implemented due to low literacy levels and poor socioeconomic status.
	+ The motivation to seek care for a febrile child was the condition of the child in an overwhelming 91.8% of the study population.
	+ Only 15.5% knew chloroquine to be the best treatment for malaria, and the most obvious reason was low literacy in this rural population.
	+ Despite this, the attitude toward vector control programs was very positive, and the practice of going to government hospitals/doctors for malaria treatment was found at a healthy rate of 72%.
	+ The results are in agreement with those reported by Hlongwana et al. and demonstrate that respondents had good knowledge about malaria signs and symptoms.
	+ Creating awareness across all socioeconomic domains and identifying possible bottlenecks is crucial for effective malaria prevention.

<summary>
• Recent advances in molecular biology and microscopy technologies have revealed the higher-order folding of the genome and its role in regulating gene expression and DNA replication.
• The genome is folded into hierarchical structures, including chromosome territories, genomic compartments, and topologically associating domains (TADs), with specific long-range looping interactions occurring within each.
• TADs, which range from 100 kb to 1 mb in size, exhibit higher frequency of physical contacts between genes and their regulatory regions.
• TAD boundaries are stable across different species, cell types, and cellular conditions, and are enriched for certain histone marks, CTCF, cohesin, and the timing of replication domains.
• In Drosophila, the combinatorial binding of different types of insulators is associated with the strength of the TAD boundary.
• Brg1, the major ATPase subunit of the SWI/SNF chromatin remodeling complex, contributes to TAD boundary strength and regulates nucleosome occupancy and possibly ctf1 localization.
• Brg1 loss may disrupt chromatin accessibility and prevent the binding of transcription factors and/or chromatin modifiers at TAD boundaries, leading to reduced nucleosome occupancy and altered boundary strength.
</summary>

• Recent advances in molecular biology and microscopy technologies have enhanced our understanding of the higher-order folding of the genome.
• The genome is folded into hierarchical structures, including chromosome territories, genomic compartments, and topologically associating domains (TADs).

• TAD boundaries are stable across different species, cell types, and cellular conditions.
• Brg1, the major ATPase subunit of the SWI/SNF chromatin remodeling complex, contributes to TAD boundary strength.

* The text discusses the use of statistical modeling, specifically Poisson and Negative Binomial regressions with zero inflated, to investigate count data, particularly the number of failed courses and semesters in university students.
* Poisson distribution is used when mean and variance are equal, while Negative Binomial distribution is preferred when variance is larger than mean (overdispersion).
* Poisson regression is a subset of Generalized Linear Model (GLM) and is used for count variables.
* Zero inflated Poisson or Negative Binomial distributions are used when count variables have an inflation in zero.
* Several studies have applied statistical modeling, including Negative Binomial and Poisson regressions, as well as zero inflated models, to various count data.
* Rafiee (1) used Negative Binomial distribution to model hospitalization periods after childbirth, while Wong and Lam (2) used zero inflated Poisson regression for modeling dmf in students' health situations.
* Barondess et al (3) used zero inflated Poisson regression to model cigarettes used by new smokers of different races in the USA in 2010.
* Mohammadfam et al (4) applied a Poisson regression with zero inflation to model the number of work accidents in 2009.
* The text also mentions the application of these methods to modeling educational count data, such as the number of failed courses or semesters in university students.
* The study aims to apply statistical modeling, specifically Poisson and Negative Binomial regressions with zero inflated, to model the number of failed courses and semesters in students of Iran University of Medical Sciences.

• Ecdhfr is an enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of 7,8-dihydrofolate (dhf) to 5,6,7,8-tetrahydrofolate (thf) using NADPH.
• The active site of ecdhfr undergoes significant structural rearrangements during the catalytic cycle, making it an ideal system for studying how conformational changes affect the active site electrostatic environment.
• Thiocyanate probes were incorporated into ecdhfr at specific locations to analyze the electrostatics and degree of hydration of the microenvironments surrounding the probes.
• The electrostatic interactions arising from the active site microenvironments surrounding the probes led to different observed cn vibrational stretching frequencies and c nmr chemical shifts along the catalytic cycle.
• Experimental data showed changes in the active site electrostatic environment due to structural rearrangements, and further insights were obtained through quantum mechanical and molecular mechanical analyses of classical molecular dynamics simulations.
• The integrated approach provided valuable insights into the interplay between electrostatic and conformational changes along the catalytic cycle of ecdhfr.

• Hypothesized that transcriptomic networks specifically observed in infected cells but not in neighboring uninfected cells would represent cell-intrinsic pathogen-induced changes

• Appetite regulation is complex, involving both physiological and environmental inputs
• Early theories focused on signals from glucose metabolism, amino acids, or adipose tissue
• More recent models emphasize inputs from adipose tissue and the gastrointestinal tract, along with sensory features of food
• Major signals include leptin from adipose tissue and hormones from specialized cells in the gastrointestinal tract
• Models contribute to understanding the regulation of body weight by identifying specific molecular signals
• Energy balance studies propose that energy intake is determined by energy expenditure
• RMR is the largest component of daily energy expenditure and could provide a tonic signal of energy demand
</summary>

• Early theories of appetite regulation
  • Glucostatic hypothesis: based on signals from glucose metabolism (Mayer, 1955)
  • Aminostatic hypothesis: based on signals from amino acids or proteins (Mellinkoff et al., 1956)
  • Lipostatic hypothesis: based on signals from adipose tissue (Kennedy, 1953)

• Recent models of appetite regulation
  • Emphasize inputs from adipose tissue and gastrointestinal tract (Schwartz and Morton, 2001; Keesey and Powley, 2008)
  • Major signals include leptin, ghrelin, PYY, GLP-1, CCK, amylin, and insulin
  • Models account for the regulation of appetite and contribute to the regulation of body weight

• Energy balance studies
  • Propose that any increase in energy expenditure will be met with an equivalent increase in energy intake (Mayer et al., 1956)
  • Edholm's experimental studies revealed no correlation between energy expenditure and energy intake in a single day but a good correlation over 2 weeks
  • RMR is the largest component of daily energy expenditure and could provide a tonic signal of energy demand

• Polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) is a widely used material in prosthetic dentistry for denture base fabrication.
• Heat-polymerized PMMA resin is commonly used due to its excellent esthetics, low water sorption, and simple processing technique.
• Compression molding technique is used for heat-polymerized PMMA resin, but it has high processing stresses leading to dimensional changes and inaccuracies.
• Chemically activated resins are less frequently used due to their higher solubility and inferior color stability.
• Injection molding technique is an alternative with reduced processing time, lower cost, and availability of resin reservoir to compensate for shrinkage.

• Bonding between denture teeth and denture base resins is crucial to prevent debonding, which is a common problem.
• Previous studies reported that 26-33% of denture repairs are due to debonded teeth.
• Factors affecting bond strength include material properties, processing factors, and available monomer during processing.

• Attempts to increase bond strength include surface treatments such as monomer application, grinding, and mechanical retention features.
• Clancy and Boyer's study found that heat-polymerized resin had the strongest bonding to plastic teeth.
• This study aimed to evaluate the effect of surface treatments on shear bond strength of denture teeth to heat-polymerized and autopolymerized denture base resins.

- Major depression (MD) is a leading cause of disability and is projected to become the second leading contributor to the global burden of disease by 2020.1,2
- Approximately 40% of patients with MD do not respond satisfactorily to available antidepressant medications and psychotherapies.1,3
- Treatment-resistant depression (TRD) is a challenge in mental health care despite the understanding of psychosocial and biological markers and the availability of multiple therapeutic options.4

<summary>
• Chronic kidney diseases, including urinary tract obstruction, lead to structural changes and fibrosis in the kidney.
• Urinary tract obstruction is characterized by tubular atrophy or dilation, tubular cell death, interstitial leukocyte infiltration, and increased interstitial matrix deposition.
• Taurine, an organic acid, has been shown to have beneficial effects on renal fibrosis caused by cisplatin, diabetic nephropathy, and age-related changes.
• Taxol, a microtubule stabilizer, has been reported to ameliorate fibrosis in the ureteral obstruction rat kidney model and in polycystic kidney disease.

• Experimental study to determine the effects of taurine and taxol on tubulointerstitial fibrosis and renal histology in a rat model of ureteral obstruction.
• Stereological survey used to investigate structural changes in the kidney, including the volume of cortex, medulla, glomeruli, tubules, and vessels.

• Ureteral obstruction resulted in renal disruption, tubular atrophy, degeneration, necrosis, and fibrosis.
• Taxol and taurine treatments led to preservation of renal structure and reduction in fibrosis.

• Taxol treatment decreased degenerative tubules and necrotic tissue volumes by 42% and 53%, respectively.
• Taurine treatment increased degenerative tubules volume 1.8-fold but decreased necrotic and fibrotic tissue volumes 63%.

• Taxol and taurine treatments preserved the length of tubules and vessels, with taxol being more effective.
</summary>
